Text

[Northanger Abbey]1-northanger abbey by [Jane Austen]75-jane austen ( 1803 ) Contents ADVERTISEMENT BY [THE AUTHORESS]194-the authoress , TO [NORTHANGER ABBEY]1-northanger abbey CHAPTER 1 CHAPTER 2 CHAPTER 3 CHAPTER 4 CHAPTER 5 CHAPTER 6 CHAPTER 7 CHAPTER 8 CHAPTER 9 CHAPTER 10 CHAPTER 11 CHAPTER 12 CHAPTER 13 CHAPTER 14 CHAPTER 15 CHAPTER 16 CHAPTER 17 CHAPTER 18 CHAPTER 19 CHAPTER 20 CHAPTER 21 CHAPTER 22 CHAPTER 23 CHAPTER 24 CHAPTER 25 CHAPTER 26 CHAPTER 27 CHAPTER 28 CHAPTER 29 CHAPTER 30 CHAPTER 31 A NOTE ON THE TEXT ADVERTISEMENT BY [THE AUTHORESS]194-the authoress , TO [NORTHANGER ABBEY]1-northanger abbey This little work was finished in the year 1803 , and intended for immediate publication . It was disposed of to [a bookseller]196-a bookseller , it was even advertised , and why the business proceeded no farther , [the author]197-the author has never been able to learn . That [any bookseller]198-any bookseller should think it worth - while to purchase what [he]198-any bookseller did not think it worth - while to publish seems extraordinary . But with this , neither [the author]197-the author nor [the public]200-the public have any other concern than as some observation is necessary upon those parts of the work which thirteen years have made comparatively obsolete . [The public]200-the public are entreated to bear in mind that thirteen years have passed since it was finished , many more since it was begun , and that during that period , places , manners , books , and opinions have undergone considerable changes . CHAPTER 1 [No one who had ever seen [Catherine Morland]76-catherine in [her]203-her infancy]202-no one who had ever seen catherine morland in her infancy would have supposed [her]203-her born to be [an heroine]204-an heroine . [Her]203-her situation in life , the character of [[her]203-her father]205-her father and [mother]206-mother , [her]203-her own person and disposition , were all equally against [her]203-her . [[Her]203-her father]205-her father was [a clergyman]208-a clergyman , without being neglected , or poor , and [a very respectable man]209-a very respectable man , though [his]205-her father name was [Richard]77-captain tilney — and [he]205-her father had never been handsome . [He]205-her father had a considerable independence besides two good livings — and [he]205-her father was not in the least addicted to locking up [[his]205-her father daughters]210-his daughters . [[Her]203-her mother]211-her mother was [a woman of useful plain sense , with a good temper , and , what is more remarkable , with a good constitution]212-a woman of useful plain sense , with a good temper , and , what is more remarkable , with a good constitution . [She]211-her mother had [three sons]213-three sons before [Catherine]76-catherine was born ; and instead of dying in bringing [the latter]214-the latter into [the world]215-the world , as [anybody]216-anybody might expect , [she]211-her mother still lived on — lived to have [six children]217-six children more — to see [them]217-six children growing up around [her]211-her mother , and to enjoy excellent health [herself]211-her mother . [A family of ten children]218-a family of ten children will be always called [a fine family]219-a fine family , where there are heads and arms and legs enough for the number ; but [the Morlands]78-the morlands had little other right to the word , for [they]78-the morlands were in general very plain , and [Catherine]76-catherine , for many years of [her]211-her mother life , as plain as any . [She]211-her mother had a thin awkward figure , a sallow skin without colour , dark lank hair , and strong features — so much for [[her]211-her mother person]220-her person ; and not less unpropitious for heroism seemed [her]211-her mother mind . [She]211-her mother was fond of all [boys]221-boys ’ plays , and greatly preferred cricket not merely to dolls , but to the more heroic enjoyments of infancy , nursing [a dormouse]222-a dormouse , feeding a canary - bird , or watering a rose - bush . Indeed [she]211-her mother had no taste for [a garden]223-a garden ; and if [she]211-her mother gathered flowers at all , it was chiefly for the pleasure of mischief — at least so it was conjectured from [her]211-her mother always preferring those which [she]211-her mother was forbidden to take . Such were [her]211-her mother propensities — [her]211-her mother abilities were quite as extraordinary . [She]211-her mother never could learn or understand anything before [she]211-her mother was taught ; and sometimes not even then , for [she]211-her mother was often inattentive , and occasionally stupid . [[Her]211-her mother mother]211-her mother was three months in teaching [her]211-her mother only to repeat the “ Beggar ’s Petition ”[211-her mother] ; and after all , [[her]211-her mother next sister]225-her next sister , [Sally]79-sarah , could say it better than [she]211-her mother did . Not that [Catherine]76-catherine was always stupid — by no means ; [she]211-her mother learnt the fable of “ The Hare and [Many Friends]1685-many friends ”[211-her mother] as quickly as [any girl in [England]3-england]226-any girl in england . [[Her]211-her mother mother]211-her mother wished [her]211-her mother to learn music ; and [Catherine]76-catherine was sure [she]211-her mother should like it , for [she]211-her mother was very fond of tinkling the keys of the old forlorn spinnet ; so , at eight years old [she]211-her mother began . [She]211-her mother learnt a year , and could not bear it ; and [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland , who did not insist on [[her]80-mrs. morland daughters]228-her daughters being accomplished in spite of incapacity or distaste , allowed [her]211-her mother to leave off . The day which dismissed [the music - master]229-the music - master was one of the happiest of [Catherine]76-catherine ’s life . [Her]211-her mother taste for drawing was not superior ; though whenever [she]211-her mother could obtain the outside of a letter from [[her]211-her mother mother]211-her mother or seize upon any other odd piece of paper , [she]211-her mother did what [she]211-her mother could in that way , by drawing [houses]231-houses and trees , hens and chickens , all very much like one another . Writing and accounts [she]211-her mother was taught by [[her]211-her mother father]205-her father ; French by [[her]211-her mother mother]211-her mother : [her]211-her mother proficiency in either was not remarkable , and [she]211-her mother shirked [her]211-her mother lessons in both whenever [she]211-her mother could . What [a strange , unaccountable character!—for with all these symptoms of profligacy]234-a strange , unaccountable character!—for with all these symptoms of profligacy at ten years old , [she]211-her mother had neither a bad heart nor a bad temper , was seldom stubborn , scarcely ever quarrelsome , and very kind to [the little ones]235-the little ones , with few interruptions of tyranny ; [she]211-her mother was moreover noisy and wild , hated confinement and cleanliness , and loved nothing so well in [the world]215-the world as rolling down [the green slope]237-the green slope at the back of [the house]238-the house . Such was [Catherine Morland]76-catherine at ten . At fifteen , appearances were mending ; [she]211-her mother began to curl [her]211-her mother hair and long for balls ; [her]211-her mother complexion improved , [her]211-her mother features were softened by plumpness and colour , [her]211-her mother eyes gained more animation , and [her]211-her mother figure more consequence . [Her]211-her mother love of dirt gave way to an inclination for finery , and [she]211-her mother grew clean as [she]211-her mother grew smart ; [she]211-her mother had now the pleasure of sometimes hearing [[her]211-her mother father]205-her father and [mother]206-mother remark on [her]211-her mother personal improvement . “ [Catherine]76-catherine grows quite [a good - looking girl]1686-a good - looking girl — [she]211-her mother is almost pretty to - day , ”[206-mother] were words which caught [her]211-her mother ears now and then ; and how welcome were the sounds ! to look _ almost _ pretty is an acquisition of higher delight to [a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of [her]241-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of her life than a beauty from her cradle life than a beauty from [her]241-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of her life than a beauty from her cradle cradle]241-a girl who has been looking plain the first fifteen years of her life than a beauty from her cradle can ever receive . [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland was [a very good woman]242-a very good woman , and wished to see [[her]80-mrs. morland children]243-her children everything [they]243-her children ought to be ; but [her]80-mrs. morland time was so much occupied in lying - in and teaching [the little ones]235-the little ones , that [[her]80-mrs. morland elder daughters]245-her elder daughters were inevitably left to shift for [themselves]245-her elder daughters ; and it was not very wonderful that [Catherine]76-catherine , who had by nature nothing heroic about [her]211-her mother , should prefer cricket , baseball , riding on horseback , and running about [the country]246-the country at the age of fourteen , to books — or at least books of information — for , provided that nothing like useful knowledge could be gained from [them]247-them , provided they were all story and no reflection , [she]211-her mother had never any objection to books at all . But from fifteen to seventeen [she]211-her mother was in training for [a heroine]248-a heroine ; [she]211-her mother read all such works as [heroines]249-heroines must read to supply [their]249-heroines memories with those quotations which are so serviceable and so soothing in the vicissitudes of [their]249-heroines eventful lives . From [Pope]81-pope , [she]211-her mother learnt to censure [those who “ bear about the mockery of woe]1687-those who “ bear about the mockery of woe . ”[81-pope] From [Gray]82-gray , that “ Many a flower is born to blush unseen , “[82-gray] And waste its fragrance on the desert air . ” From [Thomson]83-thomson , that — “[211-her mother] It is a delightful task “ To teach [the young idea]1688-the young idea how to shoot . ”[211-her mother] And from [Shakespeare]84-shakespeare [she]211-her mother gained a great store of information — amongst the rest , that — “ Trifles light as air , “[84-shakespeare] Are , to the jealous , confirmation strong , “ As proofs of Holy Writ . ”[84-shakespeare] That “ [The poor beetle , which [we]1690-we tread upon]1689-the poor beetle , which we tread upon , “[84-shakespeare] In corporal sufferance feels a pang as great “ As when [a giant dies]1691-a giant dies . ”[84-shakespeare] And that [a young woman in love]250-a young woman in love always looks — “ like Patience on a monument “[250-a young woman in love] Smiling at Grief . ” So far [her]211-her mother improvement was sufficient — and in many other points [she]211-her mother came on exceedingly well ; for though [she]211-her mother could not write sonnets , [she]211-her mother brought [herself]211-her mother to read them ; and though there seemed no chance of [her]211-her mother throwing a whole party into raptures by a prelude on the pianoforte , of [her]211-her mother own composition , [she]211-her mother could listen to [other people]1692-other people ’s performance with very little fatigue . [Her]211-her mother greatest deficiency was in the pencil — [she]211-her mother had no notion of drawing — not enough even to attempt a sketch of [[her]211-her mother lover]1693-her lover ’s profile , that [she]211-her mother might be detected in the design . There [she]211-her mother fell miserably short of the true heroic height . At present [she]211-her mother did not know [her]211-her mother own poverty , for [she]211-her mother had [no lover to portray]1694-no lover to portray . [She]211-her mother had reached the age of seventeen , without having seen [one amiable youth who could call forth her sensibility , without having inspired one real passion , and without having excited even any admiration but what was very moderate and very transient]1695-one amiable youth who could call forth her sensibility , without having inspired one real passion , and without having excited even any admiration but what was very moderate and very transient . This was strange indeed ! but strange things may be generally accounted for if [their]1692-other people cause be fairly searched out . There was [not one lord]1696-not one lord in [the neighbourhood]1697-the neighbourhood ; no — not even [a baronet]1698-a baronet . There was [not one family among [their]1692-other people acquaintance who had reared and supported [a boy accidentally found at [their]1692-other people door]1700-a boy accidentally found at their door]1699-not one family among their acquaintance who had reared and supported a boy accidentally found at their door — [not one young man whose origin was unknown]1701-not one young man whose origin was unknown . [[Her]211-her mother father]205-her father had [no ward]1703-no ward , and [the squire of [the parish]1705-the parish]1704-the squire of the parish no [children]1706-children . But when [a young lady]1707-a young lady is to be [a heroine]248-a heroine , the perverseness of [forty surrounding families]1709-forty surrounding families can not prevent [her]1707-a young lady . Something must and will happen to throw [a hero]1710-a hero in [her]1707-a young lady way . [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen , who owned [the chief of [the property about [Fullerton]4-fullerton , [the village]1713-the village in [Wiltshire]5-wiltshire where [the Morlands]78-the morlands lived]1712-the property about fullerton , the village in wiltshire where the morlands lived]1711-the chief of the property about fullerton , the village in wiltshire where the morlands lived , was ordered to [Bath]6-bath for the benefit of a gouty constitution — and [[his]85-mr. allen lady]1714-his lady , [a good - humoured woman , fond of [Miss Morland]86-miss morland]1715-a good - humoured woman , fond of miss morland , and probably aware that if adventures will not befall [a young lady in [[her]1716-a young lady in her own village [own village]1718-own village]1717-her own village]1716-a young lady in her own village , [she]1716-a young lady in her own village must seek [them]1716-a young lady in her own village abroad , invited [her]1716-a young lady in her own village to go with [them]1716-a young lady in her own village . [Mr.]1719-mr. and [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland were all compliance , and [Catherine]76-catherine all happiness . CHAPTER 2 In addition to what has been already said of [Catherine Morland]76-catherine ’s personal and mental endowments , when about to be launched into all the difficulties and dangers of a six weeks ’ residence in [Bath]6-bath , it may be stated , for [the reader]1720-the reader ’s more certain information , lest the following pages should otherwise fail of giving any idea of what [her]86-miss morland character is meant to be , that [her]86-miss morland heart was affectionate ; [her]86-miss morland disposition cheerful and open , without conceit or affectation of any kind — [her]86-miss morland manners just removed from the awkwardness and shyness of [a girl]1721-a girl ; [her]86-miss morland person pleasing , and , when in good looks , pretty — and [her]86-miss morland mind about as ignorant and uninformed as [the female mind]1722-the female mind at seventeen usually is . When the hour of departure drew near , the maternal anxiety of [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland will be naturally supposed to be most severe . A thousand alarming presentiments of evil to [her]80-mrs. morland beloved [Catherine]76-catherine from this terrific separation must oppress [her]80-mrs. morland heart with sadness , and drown [her]86-miss morland in tears for the last day or two of [their]1723-their being together ; and advice of the most important and applicable nature must of course flow from [her]80-mrs. morland wise lips in [their]1723-their parting conference in [[her]80-mrs. morland closet]1724-her closet . Cautions against the violence of [such noblemen and baronets]1725-such noblemen and baronets as delight in forcing [young ladies]1726-young ladies away to [some remote farm - house]1727-some remote farm - house , must , at such a moment , relieve the fulness of [her]80-mrs. morland heart . Who would not think so ? But [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland knew so little of [lords and baronets]1728-lords and baronets , that [she]80-mrs. morland entertained no notion of [their]1728-lords and baronets general mischievousness , and was wholly unsuspicious of danger to [[her]80-mrs. morland daughter]1729-her daughter from [their]1728-lords and baronets machinations . [Her]80-mrs. morland cautions were confined to the following points . “[250-a young woman in love] [I]0-i beg , [Catherine]76-catherine , [you]76-catherine will always wrap [yourself]76-catherine up very warm about the throat , when [you]76-catherine come from [the Rooms]251-the rooms at night ; and [I]0-i wish [you]76-catherine would try to keep some account of the money [you]76-catherine spend ; [I]0-i will give [you]76-catherine this little book on purpose . ” [Sally]79-sarah , or rather [Sarah]79-sarah ( for what [young lady of common gentility]1730-young lady of common gentility will reach the age of sixteen without altering [her]79-sarah name as far as [she]79-sarah can ? ) , must from situation be at this time [the intimate friend and confidante of [[her]80-mrs. morland sister]1732-her sister]1731-the intimate friend and confidante of her sister . It is remarkable , however , that [she]80-mrs. morland neither insisted on [Catherine]76-catherine ’s writing by every post , nor exacted [her]80-mrs. morland promise of transmitting the character of [every new acquaintance]1733-every new acquaintance , nor a detail of every interesting conversation that [Bath]6-bath might produce . Everything indeed relative to this important journey was done , on the part of [the Morlands]78-the morlands , with a degree of moderation and composure , which seemed rather consistent with the common feelings of common life , than with the refined susceptibilities , the tender emotions which the first separation of [a heroine]248-a heroine from [[her]80-mrs. morland family]1735-her family ought always to excite . [[Her]80-mrs. morland father]205-her father , instead of giving [her]80-mrs. morland an unlimited order on [[his]205-her father banker]1737-his banker , or even putting an hundred pounds bank - bill into [her]80-mrs. morland hands , gave [her]80-mrs. morland only ten guineas , and promised [her]80-mrs. morland more when [she]80-mrs. morland wanted it . Under these unpromising auspices , the parting took place , and the journey began . It was performed with suitable quietness and uneventful safety . [Neither robbers]1738-neither robbers nor [tempests]1739-tempests befriended [them]78-the morlands , nor [one lucky overturn]1740-one lucky overturn to introduce [them]78-the morlands to [the hero]1741-the hero . Nothing more alarming occurred than a fear , on [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen ’s side , of having once left [her]80-mrs. morland clogs behind [her]80-mrs. morland at [an inn]1742-an inn , and that fortunately proved to be groundless . [They]78-the morlands arrived at [Bath]6-bath . [Catherine]76-catherine was all eager delight — [her]80-mrs. morland eyes were [here]1743-here , there , everywhere , as [they]78-the morlands approached [[its]6-bath fine and striking environs]1744-its fine and striking environs , and afterwards drove through [those streets which conducted [them]78-the morlands to [the hotel]1746-the hotel]1745-those streets which conducted them to the hotel . [She]80-mrs. morland was come to be happy , and [she]80-mrs. morland felt happy already . [They]78-the morlands were soon settled in [comfortable lodgings in [Pulteney Street]8-pulteney street]1747-comfortable lodgings in pulteney street . It is now expedient to give some description of [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen , that [the reader]1720-the reader may be able to judge in what manner [her]80-mrs. morland actions will hereafter tend to promote the general distress of the work , and how [she]80-mrs. morland will , probably , contribute to reduce poor [Catherine]76-catherine to all the desperate wretchedness of which a last volume is capable — whether by [her]80-mrs. morland imprudence , vulgarity , or jealousy — whether by intercepting [her]80-mrs. morland letters , ruining [her]80-mrs. morland character , or turning [her]80-mrs. morland out of doors . [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen was [one of [that numerous class of females , whose society]1750-that numerous class of females , whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being [any men in [the world]215-the world who could like [them]1750-that numerous class of females , whose society well enough to marry [them]1750-that numerous class of females , whose society]1751-any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them . [She]80-mrs. morland had neither beauty , genius , accomplishment , nor manner . The air of [a gentlewoman]1753-a gentlewoman , a great deal of quiet , inactive good temper , and a trifling turn of mind were all that could account for [her]80-mrs. morland being the choice of [a sensible , intelligent man like [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen]1754-a sensible , intelligent man like mr. allen]1749-one of that numerous class of females , whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them . she had neither beauty , genius , accomplishment , nor manner . the air of a gentlewoman , a great deal of quiet , inactive good temper , and a trifling turn of mind were all that could account for her being the choice of a sensible , intelligent man like mr. allen . In one respect [she]80-mrs. morland was admirably fitted to introduce [a young lady]1707-a young lady into public , being as fond of going everywhere and seeing everything [herself]80-mrs. morland as [any young lady]1756-any young lady could be . Dress was [her]80-mrs. morland passion . [She]80-mrs. morland had a most harmless delight in being fine ; and [[our]1757-our heroine]1758-our heroine ’s entree into life could not take place till after three or four days had been spent in learning what was mostly worn , and [[her]80-mrs. morland chaperon]1759-her chaperon was provided with a dress of the newest fashion . [Catherine]76-catherine too made some purchases [herself]76-catherine , and when all these matters were arranged , the important evening came which was to usher [her]80-mrs. morland into [the Upper Rooms]1760-the upper rooms . [Her]80-mrs. morland hair was cut and dressed by the best hand , [her]80-mrs. morland clothes put on with care , and both [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen and [[her]80-mrs. morland maid]1761-her maid declared [she]80-mrs. morland looked quite as [she]80-mrs. morland should do . With such encouragement , [Catherine]76-catherine hoped at least to pass uncensured through [the crowd]1762-the crowd . As for admiration , it was always very welcome when it came , but [she]80-mrs. morland did not depend on it . [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen was so long in dressing that [they]1763-they did not enter [the ballroom]1764-the ballroom till late . The season was full , [the room]1765-the room crowded , and [the two ladies]1766-the two ladies squeezed in as well as [they]1766-the two ladies could . As for [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen , [he]85-mr. allen repaired directly to [the card - room]1767-the card - room , and left [them]1763-they to enjoy a mob by [themselves]1763-they . With more care for the safety of [her]80-mrs. morland new gown than for the comfort of [her]80-mrs. morland protégée , [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen made [her]80-mrs. morland way through [the throng of men by the door]1768-the throng of men by the door , as swiftly as the necessary caution would allow ; [Catherine]76-catherine , however , kept close at [her]80-mrs. morland side , and linked [her]80-mrs. morland arm too firmly within [[her]80-mrs. morland friend]1769-her friend ’s to be torn asunder by any common effort of [a struggling assembly]1770-a struggling assembly . But to [her]80-mrs. morland utter amazement [she]80-mrs. morland found that to proceed along [the room]1765-the room was by no means the way to disengage [themselves]1763-they from [the crowd]1762-the crowd ; it seemed rather to increase as [they]1763-they went on , whereas [she]80-mrs. morland had imagined that when once fairly within the door , [they]1763-they should easily find seats and be able to watch the dances with perfect convenience . But this was far from being the case , and though by unwearied diligence [they]1763-they gained even the top of [the room]1765-the room , [their]1763-they situation was just the same ; [they]1763-they saw nothing of [the dancers]1774-the dancers but the high feathers of [some of [the ladies]1776-the ladies]1775-some of the ladies . Still [they]1763-they moved on — something better was yet in view ; and by a continued exertion of strength and ingenuity [they]1763-they found [themselves]1763-they at last in the passage behind the highest bench . Here there was something less of [crowd]1777-crowd than below ; and hence [Miss Morland]86-miss morland had a comprehensive view of all the company beneath [her]86-miss morland , and of all the dangers of [her]86-miss morland late passage through [them]1763-they . It was a splendid sight , and [she]86-miss morland began , for the first time that evening , to feel [herself]86-miss morland at a ball : [she]86-miss morland longed to dance , but [she]86-miss morland had not an acquaintance in [the room]1765-the room . [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen did all that [she]86-miss morland could do in such a case by saying very placidly , every now and then , “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [you]252-you could dance , [[my]0-i dear]253-my dear — [I]0-i wish [you]252-you could get [a partner]254-a partner . ” For some time [[her]86-miss morland young friend]1779-her young friend felt obliged to [her]86-miss morland for these wishes ; but they were repeated so often , and proved so totally ineffectual , that [Catherine]76-catherine grew tired at last , and would thank [her]86-miss morland no more . [They]1763-they were not long able , however , to enjoy the repose of the eminence [they]1763-they had so laboriously gained . [Everybody]1780-everybody was shortly in motion for tea , and [they]1780-everybody must squeeze out like [the rest]1781-the rest . [Catherine]76-catherine began to feel something of disappointment — [she]86-miss morland was tired of being continually pressed against by [people]1782-people , [the generality of whose faces possessed nothing to interest]1783-the generality of whose faces possessed nothing to interest , and with all of whom [she]86-miss morland was so wholly unacquainted that [she]86-miss morland could not relieve the irksomeness of imprisonment by the exchange of a syllable with [any of [[her]86-miss morland fellow captives]1785-her fellow captives]1784-any of her fellow captives ; and when at last arrived in [the tea - room]1786-the tea - room , [she]86-miss morland felt yet more the awkwardness of having [no party]1787-no party to join , [no acquaintance]1788-no acquaintance to claim , [no gentleman]1789-no gentleman to assist [them]1763-they . [They]1763-they saw nothing of [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ; and after looking about [them]1763-they in vain for a more eligible situation , were obliged to sit down at the end of a table , at which [a large party]1790-a large party were already placed , without having anything to do there , or [anybody]216-anybody to speak to , except [each other]1792-each other . [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen congratulated [herself]88-mrs. allen , as soon as [they]1763-they were seated , on having preserved [her]1793-her gown from injury . “[254-a partner] It would have been very shocking to have it torn , ” said [she]1793-her , “[254-a partner] would not it ? It is such a delicate muslin . For [my]0-i part [I]0-i have not seen anything [I]0-i like so well in [the whole room]255-the whole room , [I]0-i assure [you]256-you . ” “[0-i] How uncomfortable it is , ” whispered [Catherine]76-catherine , “[0-i] not to have [a single acquaintance]257-a single acquaintance here ! ” “[0-i] Yes , [[my]0-i dear]253-my dear , ” replied [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen , with perfect serenity , “[0-i] it is very uncomfortable indeed . ” “[0-i] What shall [we]259-we do ? [The gentlemen]260-the gentlemen and [ladies at this table]261-ladies at this table look as if [they]261-ladies at this table wondered why [we]259-we came [here]1743-here — [we]259-we seem forcing [ourselves]259-we into [their]261-ladies at this table party . ” “[261-ladies at this table] Aye , so [we]259-we do . That is very disagreeable . [I]0-i wish [we]259-we had [a large acquaintance]263-a large acquaintance here . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [we]259-we had _ any;_—it would be [somebody]264-somebody to go to . ” “[264-somebody] Very true , [[my]0-i dear]253-my dear ; and if [we]259-we knew [anybody]216-anybody [we]259-we would join [them]216-anybody directly . [The Skinners]267-the skinners were here last year — [I]0-i wish [they]267-the skinners were [here]1743-here now . ” “[267-the skinners] Had not [we]259-we better go away as it is ? Here are no tea - things for [us]259-we , [you]253-my dear see . ” “[253-my dear] No more there are , indeed . How very provoking ! but [I]0-i think [we]259-we had better sit still , for one gets so tumbled in such a crowd ! how is [my]0-i head , [[my]0-i dear]253-my dear ? [Somebody]264-somebody gave [me]0-i a push that has hurt it , [I]0-i am afraid . ” “[264-somebody] No , indeed , it looks very nice . But , [dear Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen , are [you]88-mrs. allen sure there is [nobody [you]88-mrs. allen know in all this multitude of [people]1782-people]271-nobody you know in all this multitude of people ? [I]0-i think [you]88-mrs. allen _ must _ know [somebody]264-somebody . ” “[264-somebody] [I]0-i do n’t , upon [my]0-i word — [I]0-i wish [I]0-i did . [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had a large acquaintance here with all [my]0-i heart , and then [I]0-i should get [you]88-mrs. allen [a partner]254-a partner . [I]0-i should be so glad to have [you]88-mrs. allen dance . There goes [a strange - looking woman]275-a strange - looking woman ! what an odd gown [she]275-a strange - looking woman has got on ! how old - fashioned it is ! look at the back . ” After some time [they]1794-they received an offer of tea from [one of [[their]1794-they neighbours]1796-their neighbours]1795-one of their neighbours ; it was thankfully accepted , and this introduced a light conversation with [the gentleman who offered it]1797-the gentleman who offered it , which was the only time that [anybody]216-anybody spoke to [them]1794-they during the evening , till [they]1794-they were discovered and joined by [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen when the dance was over . “[275-a strange - looking woman] Well , [Miss Morland]86-miss morland , ” said [he]0-i , directly , “[86-miss morland] [I]0-i hope [you]86-miss morland have had an agreeable ball . ” “[0-i] Very agreeable indeed , ” [she]86-miss morland replied , vainly endeavouring to hide a great yawn . “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [she]275-a strange - looking woman had been able to dance , ” said [[his]0-i wife]1799-his wife ; “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [we]276-we could have got [a partner]254-a partner for [her]275-a strange - looking woman . [I]0-i have been saying how glad [I]0-i should be if [the Skinners]89-the skinners were here this winter instead of last ; or if [the Parrys]90-the parrys had come , as [they]89-the skinners talked of once , [she]275-a strange - looking woman might have danced with [George Parry]91-george . [I]0-i am so sorry [she]275-a strange - looking woman has not had [a partner]254-a partner ! ” “[276-we] [We]276-we shall do better another evening [I]0-i hope , ” was [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s consolation . [The company]1800-the company began to disperse when the dancing was over — enough to leave space for [the remainder]1801-the remainder to walk about in some comfort ; and now was the time for [a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening]1802-a heroine , who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening , to be noticed and admired . Every five minutes , by removing some of [the crowd]1762-the crowd , gave greater openings for [her]275-a strange - looking woman charms . [She]275-a strange - looking woman was now seen by [many young men who had not been near [her]275-a strange - looking woman before]1804-many young men who had not been near her before . [Not one]1805-not one , however , started with rapturous wonder on beholding [her]275-a strange - looking woman , [no whisper of eager inquiry]1806-no whisper of eager inquiry ran round [the room]1765-the room , nor was [she]275-a strange - looking woman once called [a divinity]1808-a divinity by [anybody]216-anybody . Yet [Catherine]76-catherine was in very good looks , and had [the company]1800-the company only seen [her]275-a strange - looking woman three years before , [they]1800-the company would _ now _ have thought [her]275-a strange - looking woman exceedingly handsome . [She]275-a strange - looking woman _ was _ looked at , however , and with some admiration ; for , in [her]275-a strange - looking woman own hearing , [two gentlemen]1811-two gentlemen pronounced [her]275-a strange - looking woman to be [a pretty girl]1812-a pretty girl . Such words had [their]1811-two gentlemen due effect ; [she]275-a strange - looking woman immediately thought the evening pleasanter than [she]275-a strange - looking woman had found it before — [her]275-a strange - looking woman humble vanity was contented — [she]275-a strange - looking woman felt more obliged to [the two young men]1813-the two young men for this simple praise than [a true quality heroine]1814-a true quality heroine would have been for fifteen sonnets in celebration of [her]275-a strange - looking woman charms , and went to [her]275-a strange - looking woman chair in good humour with [everybody]1780-everybody , and perfectly satisfied with [her]275-a strange - looking woman share of public attention . CHAPTER 3 Every morning now brought [its]1816-its regular duties — [shops]1817-shops were to be visited ; [some new part of [the town]1819-the town]1818-some new part of the town to be looked at ; and [the Pump - room]1820-the pump - room to be attended , where [they]1811-two gentlemen paraded up and down for an hour , looking at [everybody]1780-everybody and speaking to [no one]1822-no one . The wish of [a numerous acquaintance]1823-a numerous acquaintance in [Bath]1824-bath was still uppermost with [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen , and [she]275-a strange - looking woman repeated it after every fresh proof , which every morning brought , of [her]275-a strange - looking woman knowing [nobody at all]1825-nobody at all . [They]1811-two gentlemen made [their]1811-two gentlemen appearance in [the Lower Rooms]1826-the lower rooms ; and here fortune was more favourable to [[our]1827-our heroine]1758-our heroine . [The master of the ceremonies]1829-the master of the ceremonies introduced to [her]275-a strange - looking woman [a very gentleman - like young man]1830-a very gentleman - like young man as [a partner]254-a partner ; [his]1830-a very gentleman - like young man name was [Tilney]92-miss tilney . [He]1830-a very gentleman - like young man seemed to be about four or five and twenty , was rather tall , had a pleasing countenance , a very intelligent and lively eye , and , if not quite handsome , was very near it . [His]1830-a very gentleman - like young man address was good , and [Catherine]76-catherine felt [herself]76-catherine in high luck . There was little leisure for speaking while [they]1811-two gentlemen danced ; but when [they]1811-two gentlemen were seated at tea , [she]279-madam found [him]1830-a very gentleman - like young man as agreeable as [she]279-madam had already given [him]1830-a very gentleman - like young man credit for being . [He]1830-a very gentleman - like young man talked with fluency and spirit — and there was an archness and pleasantry in [his]1830-a very gentleman - like young man manner which interested , though it was hardly understood by [her]279-madam . After chatting some time on such matters as naturally arose from the objects around [them]1811-two gentlemen , [he]1830-a very gentleman - like young man suddenly addressed [her]279-madam with—“I[0-i] have hitherto been very remiss , [madam]279-madam , in the proper attentions of [a partner here]280-a partner here ; [I]0-i have not yet asked [you]279-madam how long [you]279-madam have been in [Bath]6-bath ; whether [you]279-madam were ever [here]1743-here before ; whether [you]279-madam have been at [the Upper Rooms]1760-the upper rooms , [the theatre]283-the theatre , and the concert ; and how [you]279-madam like [the place]284-the place altogether . [I]0-i have been very negligent — but are [you]279-madam now at leisure to satisfy [me]0-i in these particulars ? If [you]279-madam are [I]0-i will begin directly . ” “[0-i] [You]279-madam need not give [yourself]279-madam that trouble , [sir]285-sir . ” “[279-madam] No trouble , [I]0-i assure [you]279-madam , [madam]279-madam . ” Then forming [his]285-sir features into a set smile , and affectedly softening [his]285-sir voice , [he]285-sir added , with a simpering air , “[0-i] Have [you]279-madam been long in [Bath]6-bath , [madam]279-madam ? ” “[279-madam] About a week , [sir]285-sir , ” replied [Catherine]76-catherine , trying not to laugh . “[279-madam] Really ! ” with affected astonishment . “[279-madam] Why should [you]279-madam be surprised , [sir]285-sir ? ” “[279-madam] Why , indeed ! ” said [he]285-sir , in [his]285-sir natural tone . “[279-madam] But some emotion must appear to be raised by [your]279-madam reply , and surprise is more easily assumed , and not less reasonable than any other . Now let [us]290-us go on . Were [you]279-madam never [here]1743-here before , [madam]279-madam ? ” “[279-madam] Never , [sir]285-sir . ” “[279-madam] Indeed ! have [you]279-madam yet honoured [the Upper Rooms]1760-the upper rooms ? ” “[285-sir] Yes , [sir]285-sir , [I]0-i was there last Monday . ” “[285-sir] Have [you]279-madam been to [the theatre]283-the theatre ? ” “[285-sir] Yes , [sir]285-sir , [I]0-i was at the play on Tuesday . ” “[0-i] To the concert ? ” “[285-sir] Yes , [sir]285-sir , on Wednesday . ” “[285-sir] And are [you]279-madam altogether pleased with [Bath]6-bath ? ” “[279-madam] Yes — [I]0-i like it very well . ” “[0-i] Now [I]0-i must give one smirk , and then [we]290-us may be rational again . ” [Catherine]76-catherine turned away [her]279-madam head , not knowing whether [she]279-madam might venture to laugh . “[0-i] [I]0-i see what [you]279-madam think of [me]0-i , ” said [he]0-i gravely—“I[279-madam] shall make but a poor figure in [your]279-madam journal to - morrow . ” “[0-i] [My]0-i journal ! ” “[0-i] Yes , [I]0-i know exactly what [you]279-madam will say : Friday , went to [the Lower Rooms]1826-the lower rooms ; wore [my]0-i sprigged muslin robe with blue trimmings — plain black shoes — appeared to much advantage ; but was strangely harassed by [a queer , half - witted man]300-a queer , half - witted man , who would make [me]0-i dance with [him]300-a queer , half - witted man , and distressed [me]0-i by [his]300-a queer , half - witted man nonsense . ” “[300-a queer , half - witted man] Indeed [I]0-i shall say no such thing . ” “[0-i] Shall [I]0-i tell [you]279-madam what [you]279-madam ought to say ? ” “[0-i] If [you]279-madam please . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i danced with [a very agreeable young man]301-a very agreeable young man , introduced by [Mr. King]93-mr. king ; had a great deal of conversation with [him]301-a very agreeable young man — seems a most extraordinary genius — hope [I]0-i may know more of [him]301-a very agreeable young man . _ That _ , [madam]279-madam , is what [I]0-i _ wish _ [you]279-madam to say . ” “[0-i] But , perhaps , [I]0-i keep no journal . ” “[0-i] Perhaps [you]279-madam are not sitting in [this room]303-this room , and [I]0-i am not sitting by [you]279-madam . These are points in which a doubt is equally possible . Not keep a journal ! how are [[your]279-madam absent cousins]304-your absent cousins to understand the tenor of [your]279-madam life in [Bath]6-bath without [one]305-one ? How are the civilities and compliments of every day to be related as they ought to be , unless noted down every evening in a journal ? How are [your]279-madam various dresses to be remembered , and the particular state of [your]279-madam complexion , and curl of [your]279-madam hair to be described in all their diversities , without having constant recourse to a journal ? [[My]0-i dear madam]306-my dear madam , [I]0-i am not so ignorant of [young ladies]1726-young ladies ’ ways as [you]279-madam wish to believe [me]0-i ; it is this delightful habit of journaling which largely contributes to form the easy style of writing for which [ladies are so generally celebrated]308-ladies are so generally celebrated . [Everybody]1780-everybody allows that the talent of writing agreeable letters is peculiarly female . [Nature]94-nature may have done something , but [I]0-i am sure it must be essentially assisted by the practice of keeping a journal . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have sometimes thought , ” said [Catherine]76-catherine , doubtingly , “[0-i] whether [ladies]310-ladies do write so much better letters than [gentlemen]311-gentlemen ! that is — [I]0-i should not think the superiority was always on [our]312-our side . ” “[0-i] As far as [I]0-i have had opportunity of judging , it appears to [me]0-i that the usual style of letter - writing among [women]313-women is faultless , except in three particulars . ” “[314-they] And what are [they]314-they ? ” “[314-they] A general deficiency of subject , a total inattention to stops , and a very frequent ignorance of grammar . ” “[0-i] Upon [my]0-i word ! [i]0-i need not have been afraid of disclaiming the compliment . [You]279-madam do not think too highly of [us]312-our in that way . ” “[279-madam] [I]0-i should no more lay it down as a general rule that [women]313-women write better letters than [men]316-men , than that [they]313-women sing better duets , or draw better landscapes . In every power , of which taste is the foundation , excellence is pretty fairly divided between [the sexes]317-the sexes . ” [They]312-our were interrupted by [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen : “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]253-my dear [Catherine]76-catherine , ” said [she]279-madam , “[0-i] do take this pin out of [my]0-i sleeve ; [I]0-i am afraid it has torn a hole already ; [I]0-i shall be quite sorry if it has , for this is a favourite gown , though it cost but nine shillings a yard . ” “[279-madam] That is exactly what [I]0-i should have guessed it , [madam]279-madam , ” said [Mr. Tilney]95-henry , looking at the muslin . “[279-madam] Do [you]0-i understand muslins , [sir]285-sir ? ” “[0-i] Particularly well ; [I]0-i always buy [my]0-i own cravats , and am allowed to be [an excellent judge]321-an excellent judge ; and [[my]0-i sister]322-my sister has often trusted [me]0-i in the choice of a gown . [I]0-i bought one for [her]322-my sister the other day , and it was pronounced to be a prodigious bargain by [every lady who saw it]323-every lady who saw it . [I]0-i gave but five shillings a yard for it , and a true Indian muslin . ” [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen was quite struck by [his]285-sir genius . “[316-men] [Men]316-men commonly take so little notice of those things , ” said [she]279-madam ; “[316-men] [I]0-i can never get [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen to know one of [my]0-i gowns from another . [You]85-mr. allen must be a great comfort to [[your]85-mr. allen sister]325-your sister , [sir]285-sir . ” “[85-mr. allen] [I]0-i hope [I]0-i am , [madam]279-madam . ” “[279-madam] And pray , [sir]285-sir , what do [you]285-sir think of [Miss Morland]86-miss morland ’s gown ? ” “[285-sir] It is very pretty , [madam]279-madam , ” said [he]0-i , gravely examining it ; “[279-madam] but [I]0-i do not think it will wash well ; [I]0-i am afraid it will fray . ” “[0-i] How can [you]285-sir , ” said [Catherine]76-catherine , laughing , “[285-sir] be so — ” [She]279-madam had almost said “[285-sir] strange . ” “[285-sir] [I]0-i am quite of [your]285-sir opinion , [sir]285-sir , ” replied [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen ; “[0-i] and so [I]0-i told [Miss Morland]86-miss morland when [she]86-miss morland bought it . ” “[0-i] But then [you]279-madam know , [madam]279-madam , muslin always turns to some account or other ; [Miss Morland]86-miss morland will get enough out of it for a handkerchief , or a cap , or a cloak . Muslin can never be said to be wasted . [I]0-i have heard [[my]0-i sister]322-my sister say so forty times , when [she]322-my sister has been extravagant in buying more than [she]322-my sister wanted , or careless in cutting it to pieces . ” “[322-my sister] [Bath]6-bath is [a charming place]333-a charming place , [sir]285-sir ; there are [so many good shops here]335-so many good shops here . [We]336-we are sadly off in [the country]246-the country ; not but what [we]336-we have [very good shops in [Salisbury]9-salisbury]338-very good shops in salisbury , but it is so far to go — eight miles is a long way ; [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen says it is nine , measured nine ; but [I]0-i am sure it can not be more than eight ; and it is such a fag — [I]0-i come back tired to death . Now , here [one]305-one can step out of doors and get a thing in five minutes . ” [Mr. Tilney]95-henry was polite enough to seem interested in what [she]340-you said ; and [she]340-you kept [him]95-henry on the subject of muslins till the dancing recommenced . [Catherine]76-catherine feared , as [she]340-you listened to [their]336-we discourse , that [he]95-henry indulged [himself]95-henry a little too much with the foibles of [others]1832-others . “[340-you] What are [you]340-you thinking of so earnestly ? ” said [he]95-henry , as [they]336-we walked back to [the ballroom]1764-the ballroom ; “[340-you] not of [[your]340-you partner]341-your partner , [I]0-i hope , for , by that shake of the head , [your]340-you meditations are not satisfactory . ” [Catherine]76-catherine coloured , and said , “[0-i] [I]0-i was not thinking of anything . ” “[0-i] That is artful and deep , to be sure ; but [I]0-i had rather be told at once that [you]340-you will not tell [me]0-i . ” “[340-you] Well then , [I]0-i will not . ” “[340-you] Thank [you]340-you ; for now [we]342-we shall soon be acquainted , as [I]0-i am authorized to tease [you]340-you on this subject whenever [we]342-we meet , and nothing in [the world]215-the world advances intimacy so much . ” [They]336-we danced again ; and , when the assembly closed , parted , on [the lady]1834-the lady ’s side at least , with a strong inclination for continuing the acquaintance . Whether [she]1834-the lady thought of [him]0-i so much , while [she]1834-the lady drank [her]1834-the lady warm wine and water , and prepared [herself]1834-the lady for bed , as to dream of [him]0-i when there , can not be ascertained ; but [I]0-i hope it was no more than in a slight slumber , or a morning doze at most ; for if it be true , as [a celebrated writer]1835-a celebrated writer has maintained , that [no young lady]1836-no young lady can be justified in falling in love before [the gentleman]1837-the gentleman ’s love is declared,[1 ] it must be very improper that [a young lady]1707-a young lady should dream of [a gentleman]1839-a gentleman before [the gentleman]1837-the gentleman is first known to have dreamt of [her]1707-a young lady . How proper [Mr. Tilney]95-henry might be as [a dreamer]1841-a dreamer or [a lover]1842-a lover had not yet perhaps entered [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s head , but that [he]0-i was not objectionable as a common acquaintance for [[his]0-i young charge]1843-his young charge [he]0-i was on inquiry satisfied ; for [he]0-i had early in the evening taken pains to know who [[her]1707-a young lady partner]1844-her partner was , and had been assured of [Mr. Tilney]95-henry ’s being [a clergyman]208-a clergyman , and of [a very respectable family in [Gloucestershire]10-gloucestershire]1846-a very respectable family in gloucestershire . [ 1 ] Vide a letter from [Mr. Richardson]96-mr. richardson , No . 97 , Vol . ii , Rambler . CHAPTER 4 With more than usual eagerness did [Catherine]76-catherine hasten to [the pump - room]1820-the pump - room the next day , secure within [herself]76-catherine of seeing [Mr. Tilney]95-henry [there]1848-there before the morning were over , and ready to meet [him]95-henry with a smile ; but no smile was demanded — [Mr. Tilney]95-henry did not appear . [Every creature in Bath]1849-every creature in bath , except [himself]95-henry , was to be seen in [the room]1765-the room at different periods of the fashionable hours ; [crowds of people]1851-crowds of people were every moment passing in and out , up the steps and down ; people whom [nobody cared about]1852-nobody cared about , and [nobody wanted to see]1853-nobody wanted to see ; and [he]95-henry only was absent . “[0-i] What [a delightful place Bath]344-a delightful place bath is , ” said [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen as [they]345-we sat down near the great clock , after parading [the room]1765-the room till [they]345-we were tired ; “[0-i] and how pleasant it would be if [we]345-we had any acquaintance [here]1743-here . ” This sentiment had been uttered so often in vain that [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen had no particular reason to hope it would be followed with more advantage now ; but [we]345-we are told to “[0-i] despair of nothing [we]345-we would attain , ” as “[0-i] unwearied diligence [our]345-we point would gain ” ; and the unwearied diligence with which [she]279-madam had every day wished for the same thing was at length to have its just reward , for hardly had [she]279-madam been seated ten minutes before [a lady of about [her]1855-a lady of about her own age own age]1855-a lady of about her own age , who was sitting by [her]279-madam , and had been looking at [her]279-madam attentively for several minutes , addressed [her]279-madam with great complaisance in these words : “[0-i] [I]0-i think , [madam]279-madam , [I]0-i can not be mistaken ; it is a long time since [I]0-i had the pleasure of seeing [you]279-madam , but is not [your]279-madam name [Allen]88-mrs. allen ? ” This question answered , as it readily was , [the stranger]1856-the stranger pronounced [hers]279-madam to be [Thorpe]97-miss thorpe ; and [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen immediately recognized the features of [a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom [she]279-madam had seen only once since [their]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages respective marriages]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages , and that many years ago . [Their]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages joy on this meeting was very great , as well it might , since [they]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages had been contented to know nothing of [each other]1792-each other for the last fifteen years . Compliments on good looks now passed ; and , after observing how time had slipped away since [they]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages were last together , how little [they]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages had thought of meeting in [Bath]6-bath , and what a pleasure it was to see [an old friend]1859-an old friend , [they]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages proceeded to make inquiries and give intelligence as to [[their]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages families]1860-their families , [sisters]1861-sisters , and [cousins]1862-cousins , talking both together , far more ready to give than to receive information , and each hearing very little of what [the other]1863-the other said . [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe , however , had one great advantage as [a talker]1864-a talker , over [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen , in [a family of children]1865-a family of children ; and when [she]98-mrs. thorpe expatiated on the talents of [[her]98-mrs. thorpe sons]1866-her sons , and the beauty of [[her]98-mrs. thorpe daughters]228-her daughters , when [she]98-mrs. thorpe related [their]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages different situations and views — that [John]99-john was at [Oxford]11-oxford , [Edward]100-edward at [Merchant Taylors]101-merchant taylors ’ , and [William]102-william at [sea]1868-sea — and all of [them]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages more beloved and respected in [their]1857-a former schoolfellow and intimate , whom she had seen only once since their respective marriages different station than [any other three beings ever were]1869-any other three beings ever were , [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen had no similar information to give , no similar triumphs to press on the unwilling and unbelieving ear of [[her]98-mrs. thorpe friend]1769-her friend , and was forced to sit and appear to listen to all these maternal effusions , consoling [herself]88-mrs. allen , however , with the discovery , which [her]98-mrs. thorpe keen eyes soon made , that the lace on [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe ’s pelisse was not half so handsome as that on [her]98-mrs. thorpe own . “[88-mrs. allen] Here come [[my]0-i dear girls]348-my dear girls , ” cried [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe , pointing at [three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards [her]98-mrs. thorpe]1871-three smart - looking females who , arm in arm , were then moving towards her . “[348-my dear girls] [[My]0-i dear]253-my dear [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen , [I]0-i long to introduce [them]348-my dear girls ; [they]348-my dear girls will be so delighted to see [you]253-my dear : [the tallest]350-the tallest is [Isabella]103-isabella , [[my]0-i eldest]351-my eldest ; is not [she]103-isabella [a fine young woman]352-a fine young woman ? [The others]353-the others are very much admired too , but [I]0-i believe [Isabella]103-isabella is the handsomest . ” [The Miss Thorpes]104-the thorpes were introduced ; and [Miss Morland]86-miss morland , who had been for a short time forgotten , was introduced likewise . The name seemed to strike [them]348-my dear girls all ; and , after speaking to [her]354-her with great civility , [the eldest young lady]1872-the eldest young lady observed aloud to [the rest]1781-the rest , “[103-isabella] How excessively like [[her]354-her brother]355-her brother [Miss Morland]86-miss morland is ! ” “[86-miss morland] The very picture of [him]355-her brother indeed ! ” cried [the mother]1874-the mother — and “[355-her brother] [I]0-i should have known [her]355-her brother anywhere for [[his]355-her brother sister]356-his sister ! ” was repeated by [them]348-my dear girls all , two or three times over . For a moment [Catherine]76-catherine was surprised ; but [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe and [[her]98-mrs. thorpe daughters]228-her daughters had scarcely begun the history of [their]348-my dear girls acquaintance with [Mr. James Morland]105-james , before [she]98-mrs. thorpe remembered that [[her]98-mrs. thorpe eldest brother]1876-her eldest brother had lately formed an intimacy with [a young man of [[his]1876-her eldest brother own college]1878-his own college , of the name of [Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe]1877-a young man of his own college , of the name of thorpe ; and that [he]355-her brother had spent the last week of the Christmas vacation with [[his]355-her brother family]1879-his family , near [London]12-london . The whole being explained , many obliging things were said by [the Miss Thorpes]104-the thorpes of [their]348-my dear girls wish of being better acquainted with [her]98-mrs. thorpe ; of being considered as [already friends]1880-already friends , through the friendship of [[their]348-my dear girls brothers]1881-their brothers , etc . , which [Catherine]76-catherine heard with pleasure , and answered with all the pretty expressions [she]98-mrs. thorpe could command ; and , as the first proof of amity , [she]98-mrs. thorpe was soon invited to accept an arm of [the eldest Miss Thorpe]97-miss thorpe , and take a turn with [her]98-mrs. thorpe about [the room]1765-the room . [Catherine]76-catherine was delighted with this extension of [her]98-mrs. thorpe Bath acquaintance , and almost forgot [Mr. Tilney]95-henry while [she]98-mrs. thorpe talked to [Miss Thorpe]97-miss thorpe . Friendship is certainly the finest balm for the pangs of disappointed love . [Their]348-my dear girls conversation turned upon those subjects , of which the free discussion has generally much to do in perfecting a sudden intimacy between [two young ladies]1883-two young ladies : such as dress , balls , flirtations , and quizzes . [Miss Thorpe]97-miss thorpe , however , being four years older than [Miss Morland]86-miss morland , and at least four years better informed , had a very decided advantage in discussing such points ; [she]97-miss thorpe could compare the balls of Bath with those of [Tunbridge]13-tunbridge , its fashions with the fashions of [London]12-london ; could rectify the opinions of [[her]97-miss thorpe new friend]1884-her new friend in many articles of tasteful attire ; could discover a flirtation between [any gentleman]1885-any gentleman and [lady who only smiled on each other]1886-lady who only smiled on each other ; and point out a quiz through the thickness of [a crowd]1887-a crowd . These powers received due admiration from [Catherine]76-catherine , to whom [they]348-my dear girls were entirely new ; and the respect which [they]348-my dear girls naturally inspired might have been too great for familiarity , had not the easy gaiety of [Miss Thorpe]97-miss thorpe ’s manners , and [her]97-miss thorpe frequent expressions of delight on this acquaintance with [her]97-miss thorpe , softened down every feeling of awe , and left nothing but tender affection . [Their]348-my dear girls increasing attachment was not to be satisfied with half a dozen turns in [the pump - room]1820-the pump - room , but required , when [they]348-my dear girls all quitted it together , that [Miss Thorpe]97-miss thorpe should accompany [Miss Morland]86-miss morland to the very door of [[Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s house]1889-mr. allen ’s house ; and that [they]348-my dear girls should there part with a most affectionate and lengthened shake of hands , after learning , to [their]348-my dear girls mutual relief , that [they]348-my dear girls should see [each other]1792-each other across [the theatre]283-the theatre at night , and say [their]348-my dear girls prayers in [the same chapel]1892-the same chapel the next morning . [Catherine]76-catherine then ran directly [upstairs]1893-upstairs , and watched [Miss Thorpe]97-miss thorpe ’s progress down [the street]1894-the street from [the drawing - room]1895-the drawing - room window ; admired the graceful spirit of [her]97-miss thorpe walk , the fashionable air of [her]97-miss thorpe figure and dress ; and felt grateful , as well [she]97-miss thorpe might , for the chance which had procured [her]97-miss thorpe such [a friend]1896-a friend . [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe was [a widow]1897-a widow , and [not a very rich one]1898-not a very rich one ; [she]98-mrs. thorpe was [a good - humoured , well - meaning woman]1899-a good - humoured , well - meaning woman , and [a very indulgent mother]1900-a very indulgent mother . [[Her]98-mrs. thorpe eldest daughter]1901-her eldest daughter had great personal beauty , and [the younger ones]1902-the younger ones , by pretending to be as handsome as [[their]1902-the younger ones sister]1903-their sister , imitating [her]97-miss thorpe air , and dressing in the same style , did very well . This brief account of [the family]1904-the family is intended to supersede the necessity of a long and minute detail from [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe [herself]98-mrs. thorpe , of [her]98-mrs. thorpe past adventures and sufferings , which might otherwise be expected to occupy the three or four following chapters ; in which the worthlessness of [lords]1905-lords and [attorneys]1906-attorneys might be set forth , and conversations , which had passed twenty years before , be minutely repeated . CHAPTER 5 [Catherine]76-catherine was not so much engaged at [the theatre]283-the theatre that evening , in returning the nods and smiles of [Miss Thorpe]97-miss thorpe , though [they]1908-they certainly claimed much of [her]98-mrs. thorpe leisure , as to forget to look with an inquiring eye for [Mr. Tilney]95-henry in every box which [her]98-mrs. thorpe eye could reach ; but [she]98-mrs. thorpe looked in vain . [Mr. Tilney]95-henry was no fonder of the play than [the pump - room]1820-the pump - room . [She]98-mrs. thorpe hoped to be more fortunate the next day ; and when [her]98-mrs. thorpe wishes for fine weather were answered by seeing a beautiful morning , [she]98-mrs. thorpe hardly felt a doubt of it ; for a fine Sunday in Bath empties [every house of [its]1910-every house of its inhabitants inhabitants]1910-every house of its inhabitants , and all [the world]215-the world appears on such an occasion to walk about and tell [their]1908-they acquaintance what a charming day it is . As soon as divine service was over , [the Thorpes]104-the thorpes and [Allens]106-the allens eagerly joined [each other]1792-each other ; and after staying long enough in [the pump - room]1820-the pump - room to discover that [the crowd]1762-the crowd was insupportable , and that there was not a genteel face to be seen , which [everybody]1780-everybody discovers every Sunday throughout the season , [they]1908-they hastened away to [the Crescent]14-the crescent , to breathe the fresh air of better company . Here [Catherine]76-catherine and [Isabella]103-isabella , arm in arm , again tasted the sweets of friendship in an unreserved conversation ; [they]1908-they talked much , and with much enjoyment ; but again was [Catherine]76-catherine disappointed in [her]98-mrs. thorpe hope of reseeing [[her]98-mrs. thorpe partner]1844-her partner . [He]1844-her partner was nowhere to be met with ; every search for [him]1844-her partner was equally unsuccessful , in morning lounges or evening assemblies ; neither at [the Upper nor Lower Rooms]1917-the upper nor lower rooms , at dressed or undressed balls , was [he]1844-her partner perceivable ; nor among [the walkers]1918-the walkers , [the horsemen]1919-the horsemen , or [the curricle - drivers of the morning]1920-the curricle - drivers of the morning . [His]1844-her partner name was not in the pump - room book , and curiosity could do no more . [He]1844-her partner must be gone from [Bath]6-bath . Yet [he]1844-her partner had not mentioned that [his]1844-her partner stay would be so short ! this sort of mysteriousness , which is always so becoming in [a hero]1710-a hero , threw a fresh grace in [Catherine]76-catherine ’s imagination around [his]1844-her partner person and manners , and increased [her]98-mrs. thorpe anxiety to know more of [him]1844-her partner . From [the Thorpes]104-the thorpes [she]98-mrs. thorpe could learn nothing , for [they]104-the thorpes had been only two days in [Bath]6-bath before [they]104-the thorpes met with [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen . It was a subject , however , in which [she]98-mrs. thorpe often indulged with [[her]98-mrs. thorpe fair friend]1922-her fair friend , from whom [she]98-mrs. thorpe received every possible encouragement to continue to think of [him]1844-her partner ; and [his]1844-her partner impression on [her]98-mrs. thorpe fancy was not suffered therefore to weaken . [Isabella]103-isabella was very sure that [he]1844-her partner must be [a charming young man]1923-a charming young man , and was equally sure that [he]1844-her partner must have been delighted with [[her]98-mrs. thorpe dear]1924-her dear [Catherine]76-catherine , and would therefore shortly return . [She]103-isabella liked [him]1844-her partner the better for being [a clergyman]208-a clergyman , “[355-her brother] for [she]357-she must confess [herself]357-she very partial to the profession ” ; and something like a sigh escaped [her]103-isabella as [she]103-isabella said it . Perhaps [Catherine]76-catherine was wrong in not demanding the cause of that gentle emotion — but [she]98-mrs. thorpe was not experienced enough in the finesse of love , or the duties of friendship , to know when delicate raillery was properly called for , or when a confidence should be forced . [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen was now quite happy — quite satisfied with Bath . [She]98-mrs. thorpe had found [some acquaintance]1926-some acquaintance , had been so lucky too as to find in [them]1926-some acquaintance [the family of [a most worthy old friend]1928-a most worthy old friend]1927-the family of a most worthy old friend ; and , as the completion of good fortune , had found [these friends]1929-these friends by no means so expensively dressed as [herself]98-mrs. thorpe . [Her]98-mrs. thorpe daily expressions were no longer , “[0-i] [I]0-i wish [we]358-they had some acquaintance in [Bath]6-bath ! ” [They]358-they were changed into , “[0-i] How glad [I]0-i am [we]358-they have met with [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe ! ” and [she]98-mrs. thorpe was as eager in promoting the intercourse of [the two families]1930-the two families , as [[her]98-mrs. thorpe young charge]1931-her young charge and [Isabella]103-isabella [themselves]358-they could be ; never satisfied with the day unless [she]98-mrs. thorpe spent the chief of it by the side of [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe , in what [they]358-they called conversation , but in which there was scarcely ever any exchange of opinion , and not often any resemblance of subject , for [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe talked chiefly of [[her]98-mrs. thorpe children]243-her children , and [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen of [her]98-mrs. thorpe gowns . The progress of the friendship between [Catherine]76-catherine and [Isabella]103-isabella was quick as its beginning had been warm , and [they]358-they passed so rapidly through every gradation of increasing tenderness that there was shortly no fresh proof of it to be given to [[their]358-they friends]1933-their friends or [themselves]358-they . [They]358-they called [each other]1792-each other by [their]358-they Christian name , were always arm in arm when [they]358-they walked , pinned up [each other]1792-each other ’s train for the dance , and were not to be divided in the set ; and if a rainy morning deprived [them]358-they of other enjoyments , [they]358-they were still resolute in meeting in defiance of wet and dirt , and shut [themselves]358-they up , to read novels together . Yes , novels ; for [I]98-mrs. thorpe will not adopt that ungenerous and impolitic custom so common with [novel - writers]1936-novel - writers , of degrading by [their]1936-novel - writers contemptuous censure the very performances , to the number of which [they]1936-novel - writers are [themselves]1936-novel - writers adding — joining with [[their]1936-novel - writers greatest enemies]1937-their greatest enemies in bestowing the harshest epithets on such works , and scarcely ever permitting [them]1936-novel - writers to be read by [[their]1936-novel - writers own heroine]1938-their own heroine , who , if [she]1938-their own heroine accidentally take up a novel , is sure to turn over its insipid pages with disgust . Alas ! if [the heroine of one novel]1939-the heroine of one novel be not patronized by [the heroine of another]1940-the heroine of another , from whom can [she]1938-their own heroine expect protection and regard ? [I]98-mrs. thorpe can not approve of it . Let [us]1941-our leave it to [the reviewers]1942-the reviewers to abuse such effusions of fancy at [their]1942-the reviewers leisure , and over every new novel to talk in threadbare strains of the trash with which the press now groans . Let [us]1941-our not desert [one another]1943-one another ; [we]1941-our are [an injured body]1944-an injured body . Although [our]1941-our productions have afforded more extensive and unaffected pleasure than those of any other literary corporation in [the world]215-the world , no species of composition has been so much decried . From pride , ignorance , or fashion , [[our]1941-our foes]1946-our foes are almost as many as [[our]1941-our readers]1947-our readers . And while the abilities of the nine - hundredth abridger of the History of [England]3-england , or of [the man who collects and publishes in a volume some dozen lines of Milton , Pope]1948-the man who collects and publishes in a volume some dozen lines of milton , pope , and Prior , with a paper from the Spectator , and a chapter from Sterne , are eulogized by a thousand pens — there seems almost a general wish of decrying the capacity and undervaluing the labour of [the novelist , and of slighting the performances which have only genius , wit , and taste to recommend them]1949-the novelist , and of slighting the performances which have only genius , wit , and taste to recommend them . “[98-mrs. thorpe] [I]0-i am [no novel - reader]359-no novel - reader — [I]0-i seldom look into novels — Do not imagine that _ [I]0-i _ often read novels — It is really very well for a novel . ” Such is the common ca nt . “[0-i] And what are [you]0-i reading , [Miss]360-miss — — ? ” “[360-miss] Oh ! it is only a novel ! ” replies [the young lady]1950-the young lady , while [she]1950-the young lady lays down [her]1950-the young lady book with affected indifference , or momentary shame . “[360-miss] It is only [Cecilia]107-cecilia , or [Camilla]108-camilla , or [Belinda]109-isabella ” ; or , in short , only some work in which the greatest powers of the mind are displayed , in which the most thorough knowledge of human nature , the happiest delineation of its varieties , the liveliest effusions of wit and humour , are conveyed to [the world]215-the world in the best - chosen language . Now , had [the same young lady]1952-the same young lady been engaged with a volume of [the Spectator]1953-the spectator , instead of such a work , how proudly would [she]1952-the same young lady have produced the book , and told its name ; though the chances must be against [her]1952-the same young lady being occupied by any part of that voluminous publication , of which either the matter or manner would not disgust [a young person of taste]1954-a young person of taste : the substance of its papers so often consisting in the statement of improbable circumstances , unnatural characters , and topics of conversation which no longer concern [anyone living]1955-anyone living ; and [their]1955-anyone living language , too , frequently so coarse as to give no very favourable idea of the age that could endure it . CHAPTER 6 The following conversation , which took place between [the two friends]1956-the two friends in [the pump - room]1820-the pump - room one morning , after [an acquaintance of eight or nine days]1958-an acquaintance of eight or nine days , is given as a specimen of [their]1956-the two friends very warm attachment , and of the delicacy , discretion , originality of thought , and literary taste which marked the reasonableness of that attachment . [They]1956-the two friends met by appointment ; and as [Isabella]109-isabella had arrived nearly five minutes before [[her]109-isabella friend]1769-her friend , [her]109-isabella first address naturally was , “[0-i] [[My]0-i dearest creature]361-my dearest creature , what can have made [you]361-my dearest creature so late ? [I]0-i have been waiting for [you]361-my dearest creature at least this age ! ” “[0-i] Have [you]361-my dearest creature , indeed ! [i]0-i am very sorry for it ; but really [I]0-i thought [I]0-i was in very good time . It is but just one . [I]0-i hope [you]361-my dearest creature have not been [here]1743-here long ? ” “[0-i] Oh ! these ten ages at least . [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i have been [here]1743-here this half hour . But now , let [us]364-us go and sit down at the other end of [the room]1765-the room , and enjoy [ourselves]364-us . [I]0-i have an hundred things to say to [you]361-my dearest creature . In the first place , [I]0-i was so afraid it would rain this morning , just as [I]0-i wanted to set off ; it looked very showery , and that would have thrown [me]0-i into agonies ! do [you]361-my dearest creature know , [I]0-i saw the prettiest hat [you]361-my dearest creature can imagine , in a shop window in [Milsom Street]15-milsom street just now — very like [yours]361-my dearest creature , only with coquelicot ribbons instead of green ; [I]0-i quite longed for it . But , [[my]0-i dearest]366-my dearest [Catherine]76-catherine , what have [you]361-my dearest creature been doing with [yourself]361-my dearest creature all this morning ? Have [you]361-my dearest creature gone on with [Udolpho]110-udolpho ? ” “[110-udolpho] Yes , [I]0-i have been reading it ever since [I]0-i woke ; and [I]0-i am got to the black veil . ” “[361-my dearest creature] Are [you]361-my dearest creature , indeed ? How delightful ! oh ! [i]0-i would not tell [you]361-my dearest creature what is behind the black veil for [the world]215-the world ! are not [you]361-my dearest creature wild to know ? ” “[361-my dearest creature] Oh ! yes , quite ; what can it be ? But do not tell [me]0-i — [I]0-i would not be told upon any account . [I]0-i know it must be a skeleton , [I]0-i am sure it is [Laurentina]111-laurentina ’s skeleton . Oh ! [i]0-i am delighted with the book ! [i]0-i should like to spend [my]0-i whole life in reading it . [I]0-i assure [you]361-my dearest creature , if it had not been to meet [you]361-my dearest creature , [I]0-i would not have come away from it for [all the world]368-all the world . ” “[369-dear creature] [Dear creature]369-dear creature ! how much [I]0-i am obliged to [you]361-my dearest creature ; and when [you]361-my dearest creature have finished [Udolpho]110-udolpho , [we]370-we will read the Italian together ; and [I]0-i have made out a list of ten or twelve more of the same kind for [you]361-my dearest creature . ” “[0-i] Have [you]361-my dearest creature , indeed ! how glad [I]0-i am ! what are [they all]371-they ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i will read [you]361-my dearest creature [their]371-they names directly ; here they are , in [my]0-i pocketbook . [She]114-miss andrews is netting [herself]114-miss andrews the sweetest cloak [you]361-my dearest creature can conceive . There is nothing [I]0-i would not do for [those who are really [[my]0-i friends]380-my friends]379-those who are really my friends . [I]0-i have no notion of loving [people]1782-people by halves ; it is not [my]0-i nature . [My]0-i attachments are always excessively strong . [I]0-i told [Captain Hunt]115-captain hunt at one of [[our]382-our assemblies]383-our assemblies this winter that if [he]115-captain hunt was to tease [me]0-i all night , [I]0-i would not dance with [him]115-captain hunt , unless [he]115-captain hunt would allow [Miss Andrews]114-miss andrews to be as beautiful as [an angel]377-an angel . [The men]378-the men think [us]382-our incapable of real friendship , [you]386-you know , and [I]0-i am determined to show [them]378-the men the difference . Now , if [I]0-i were to hear [anybody]216-anybody speak slightingly of [you]386-you , [I]0-i should fire up in a moment : but that is not at all likely , for _ [you]386-you _ are just [the kind of girl to be a great favourite]388-the kind of girl to be a great favourite with [the men]378-the men . ” “[0-i] Oh , dear ! ” cried [Catherine]76-catherine , colouring . “[0-i] How can [you]0-i say so ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i know [you]386-you very well ; [you]386-you have so much animation , which is exactly what [Miss Andrews]114-miss andrews wants , for [I]0-i must confess there is something amazingly insipid about [her]114-miss andrews . Oh ! [i]0-i must tell [you]386-you , that just after [we]390-we parted yesterday , [I]0-i saw [a young man]391-a young man looking at [you]386-you so earnestly — [I]0-i am sure [he]391-a young man is in love with [you]386-you . ” [Catherine]76-catherine coloured , and disclaimed again . [Isabella]109-isabella laughed . “[391-a young man] It is very true , upon [my]0-i honour , but [I]0-i see how it is ; [you]386-you are indifferent to [everybody]1780-everybody ’s admiration , except that of [one gentleman]393-one gentleman , who shall be nameless . Nay , [I]0-i can not blame you”—speaking more seriously—“your[0-i] feelings are easily understood . Where the heart is really attached , [I]0-i know very well how little one can be pleased with the attention of [anybody else]394-anybody else . Everything is so insipid , so uninteresting , that does not relate to the beloved object ! Let [us]407-us drop the subject . ” [Catherine]76-catherine , in some amazement , complied , and after remaining a few moments silent , was on the point of reverting to what interested [her]1960-her at that time rather more than anything else in [the world]215-the world , [Laurentina]111-laurentina ’s skeleton , when [[her]1960-her friend]1769-her friend prevented [her]1960-her , by saying , “[0-i] For heaven ’s sake ! CHAPTER 7 Half a minute conducted [them]416-we through [the pump - yard]1969-the pump - yard to the archway , opposite [Union Passage]21-union passage ; but here [they]416-we were stopped . [Everybody acquainted with]1970-everybody acquainted with [Bath]6-bath may remember the difficulties of crossing [Cheap Street]22-cheap street at this point ; it is indeed [a street of so impertinent a nature]1971-a street of so impertinent a nature , so unfortunately connected with [the great [London]12-london and [Oxford]11-oxford roads]1972-the great london and oxford roads , and [the principal inn of [the city]1974-the city]1973-the principal inn of the city , that a day never passes in which parties of [ladies]310-ladies , however important [their]416-we business , whether in quest of pastry , millinery , or even ( as in the present case ) of [young men]1976-young men , are not detained on one side or other by [carriages]1977-carriages , [horsemen]1978-horsemen , or [carts]1979-carts .
