To pass between [lodges of a modern appearance]2653-lodges of a modern appearance , to find [herself]1284-the wretched matilda with such ease in [the very precincts of [the abbey]1248-the abbey]2654-the very precincts of the abbey , and driven so rapidly along [a smooth , level road of fine gravel]2656-a smooth , level road of fine gravel , without obstacle , alarm , or solemnity of any kind , struck [her]1284-the wretched matilda as odd and inconsistent . [She]1284-the wretched matilda was not long at leisure , however , for such considerations . A sudden scud of rain , driving full in [her]1284-the wretched matilda face , made it impossible for [her]1284-the wretched matilda to observe anything further , and fixed all [her]1284-the wretched matilda thoughts on the welfare of [her]1284-the wretched matilda new straw bonnet ; and [she]1284-the wretched matilda was actually under the abbey walls , was springing , with [Henry]95-henry ’s assistance , from [the carriage]2004-the carriage , was beneath the shelter of [the old porch]2658-the old porch , and had even passed on to [the hall]2659-the hall , where [[her]1284-the wretched matilda friend]1769-her friend and [the General]2216-the general were waiting to welcome [her]1284-the wretched matilda , without feeling one awful foreboding of future misery to [herself]1284-the wretched matilda , or one moment ’s suspicion of any past scenes of horror being acted within the solemn edifice . The breeze had not seemed to waft the sighs of the murdered to [her]1284-the wretched matilda ; it had wafted nothing worse than a thick mizzling rain ; and having given a good shake to [her]1284-the wretched matilda habit , [she]1284-the wretched matilda was ready to be shown into [the common drawing - room]2662-the common drawing - room , and capable of considering where [she]1284-the wretched matilda was . [An abbey]2540-an abbey ! yes , it was delightful to be really in [an abbey]2540-an abbey ! but [she]1284-the wretched matilda doubted , as [she]1284-the wretched matilda looked round [the room]1765-the room , whether anything within [her]1284-the wretched matilda observation would have given [her]1284-the wretched matilda the consciousness . The furniture was in all the profusion and elegance of modern taste . The fireplace , where [she]1284-the wretched matilda had expected the ample width and ponderous carving of former times , was contracted to a Rumford , with slabs of plain though handsome marble , and ornaments over [it]1765-the room of the prettiest English china . The windows , to which [she]1284-the wretched matilda looked with peculiar dependence , from having heard [the General]2216-the general talk of [his]2216-the general preserving [them]2667-them in [their]2667-them Gothic form with reverential care , were yet less what [her]1284-the wretched matilda fancy had portrayed . To be sure , the pointed arch was preserved — the form of them was Gothic — they might be even casements — but every pane was so large , so clear , so light ! to an imagination which had hoped for the smallest divisions , and the heaviest stone - work , for painted glass , dirt , and cobwebs , the difference was very distressing . [The General]2216-the general , perceiving how [her]1284-the wretched matilda eye was employed , began to talk of the smallness of [the room]1765-the room and simplicity of the furniture , where everything , being for daily use , pretended only to comfort , etc . ; flattering [himself]2216-the general , however , that there were [some apartments in [the Abbey]1248-the abbey]2670-some apartments in the abbey not unworthy [her]1284-the wretched matilda notice — and was proceeding to mention the costly gilding of one in particular , when , taking out [his]2216-the general watch , [he]2216-the general stopped short to pronounce it with surprise within twenty minutes of five ! this seemed the word of separation , and [Catherine]76-catherine found [herself]76-catherine hurried away by [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney in such a manner as convinced [her]1284-the wretched matilda that the strictest punctuality to the family hours would be expected at [Northanger]62-northanger . Returning through [the large and lofty hall]2672-the large and lofty hall , [they]2673-they ascended [a broad staircase of shining oak]2674-a broad staircase of shining oak , which , after many flights and many landing - places , brought [them]2673-they upon a long , wide gallery . On one side [it]2672-the large and lofty hall had a range of doors , and [it]2672-the large and lofty hall was lighted on the other by windows which [Catherine]76-catherine had only time to discover looked into [a quadrangle]2675-a quadrangle , before [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney led the way into [a chamber]2676-a chamber , and scarcely staying to hope [she]1284-the wretched matilda would find [it]2676-a chamber comfortable , left [her]1284-the wretched matilda with an anxious entreaty that [she]1284-the wretched matilda would make as little alteration as possible in [her]1284-the wretched matilda dress . CHAPTER 21 A moment ’s glance was enough to satisfy [Catherine]76-catherine that [[her]1284-the wretched matilda apartment]2677-her apartment was very unlike [the one which [Henry]95-henry had endeavoured to alarm [her]1284-the wretched matilda by the description of]2678-the one which henry had endeavoured to alarm her by the description of . [It]2677-her apartment was by no means unreasonably large , and contained neither tapestry nor velvet . The walls were papered , the floor was carpeted ; the windows were neither less perfect nor more dim than those of [the drawing - room below]2679-the drawing - room below ; the furniture , though not of the latest fashion , was handsome and comfortable , and the air of [the room]1765-the room altogether far from uncheerful . [Her]1284-the wretched matilda heart instantaneously at ease on this point , [she]1284-the wretched matilda resolved to lose no time in particular examination of anything , as [she]1284-the wretched matilda greatly dreaded disobliging [the General]2216-the general by any delay . [Her]1284-the wretched matilda habit therefore was thrown off with all possible haste , and [she]1284-the wretched matilda was preparing to unpin the linen package , which the chaise - seat had conveyed for [her]1284-the wretched matilda immediate accommodation , when [her]1284-the wretched matilda eye suddenly fell on a large high chest , standing back in a deep recess on one side of the fireplace . The sight of it made [her]1284-the wretched matilda start ; and , forgetting everything else , [she]1284-the wretched matilda stood gazing on it in motionless wonder , while these thoughts crossed [her]1284-the wretched matilda : “[1284-the wretched matilda] This is strange indeed ! [i]0-i did not expect such a sight as this ! an immense heavy chest ! what can it hold ? Why should it be placed here ? Pushed back too , as if meant to be out of sight ! [i]0-i will look into it — cost [me]0-i what it may , [I]0-i will look into it — and directly too — by daylight . If [I]0-i stay till evening [my]0-i candle may go out . ” [She]1284-the wretched matilda advanced and examined it closely : it was of cedar , curiously inlaid with some darker wood , and raised , about a foot from the ground , on a carved stand of the same . The lock was silver , though tarnished from age ; at each end were the imperfect remains of handles also of silver , broken perhaps prematurely by some strange violence ; and , on the centre of the lid , was a mysterious cipher , in the same metal . [Catherine]76-catherine bent over it intently , but without being able to distinguish anything with certainty . [She]1284-the wretched matilda could not , in whatever direction [she]1284-the wretched matilda took it , believe the last letter to be a _ T ; _ and yet that it should be anything else in [that house]2682-that house was a circumstance to raise no common degree of astonishment . If not originally theirs , by what strange events could it have fallen into [the Tilney family]2590-the tilney family ? [Her]1284-the wretched matilda fearful curiosity was every moment growing greater ; and seizing , with trembling hands , the hasp of the lock , [she]1284-the wretched matilda resolved at all hazards to satisfy [herself]1284-the wretched matilda at least as to its contents . With difficulty , for something seemed to resist [her]1284-the wretched matilda efforts , [she]1284-the wretched matilda raised the lid a few inches ; but at that moment a sudden knocking at the door of [the room]1765-the room made [her]1284-the wretched matilda , starting , quit [her]1284-the wretched matilda hold , and the lid closed with alarming violence . [This ill - timed intruder]2685-this ill - timed intruder was [[Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney ’s maid]2686-miss tilney ’s maid , sent by [[her]1284-the wretched matilda mistress]2687-her mistress to be of use to [Miss Morland]86-miss morland ; and though [Catherine]76-catherine immediately dismissed [her]2686-miss tilney ’s maid , it recalled [her]1284-the wretched matilda to the sense of what [she]1284-the wretched matilda ought to be doing , and forced [her]1284-the wretched matilda , in spite of [her]1284-the wretched matilda anxious desire to penetrate this mystery , to proceed in [her]1284-the wretched matilda dressing without further delay . [Her]1284-the wretched matilda progress was not quick , for [her]1284-the wretched matilda thoughts and [her]1284-the wretched matilda eyes were still bent on the object so well calculated to interest and alarm ; and though [she]1284-the wretched matilda dared not waste a moment upon a second attempt , [she]1284-the wretched matilda could not remain many paces from the chest . At length , however , having slipped one arm into [her]1284-the wretched matilda gown , [her]1284-the wretched matilda toilette seemed so nearly finished that the impatience of [her]1284-the wretched matilda curiosity might safely be indulged . One moment surely might be spared ; and , so desperate should be the exertion of [her]1284-the wretched matilda strength , that , unless secured by supernatural means , the lid in one moment should be thrown back . With this spirit [she]1284-the wretched matilda sprang forward , and [her]1284-the wretched matilda confidence did not deceive [her]1284-the wretched matilda . [Her]1284-the wretched matilda resolute effort threw back the lid , and gave to [her]1284-the wretched matilda astonished eyes the view of a white cotton counterpane , properly folded , reposing at one end of the chest in undisputed possession ! [She]1284-the wretched matilda was gazing on it with the first blush of surprise when [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney , anxious for [[her]1284-the wretched matilda friend]1769-her friend ’s being ready , entered [the room]1765-the room , and to the rising shame of having harboured for some minutes an absurd expectation , was then added the shame of being caught in so idle a search . “[0-i] That is a curious old chest , is not it ? ” said [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney , as [Catherine]76-catherine hastily closed it and turned away to the glass . “[0-i] It is impossible to say how many generations it has been [here]1743-here . How it came to be first put in [this room]303-this room [I]0-i know not , but [I]0-i have not had it moved , because [I]0-i thought it might sometimes be of use in holding hats and bonnets . The worst of it is that its weight makes it difficult to open . In that corner , however , it is at least out of the way . ” [Catherine]76-catherine had no leisure for speech , being at once blushing , tying [her]1284-the wretched matilda gown , and forming wise resolutions with the most violent dispatch . [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney gently hinted [her]1284-the wretched matilda fear of being late ; and in half a minute [they]2690-they ran [downstairs]2119-downstairs together , in an alarm not wholly unfounded , for [General Tilney]139-general tilney was pacing [the drawing - room]1895-the drawing - room , [his]139-general tilney watch in [his]139-general tilney hand , and having , on the very instant of [their]2690-they entering , pulled the bell with violence , ordered “[1287-she] Dinner to be on table _ directly ! _ ” [Catherine]76-catherine trembled at the emphasis with which [he]139-general tilney spoke , and sat pale and breathless , in a most humble mood , concerned for [[his]139-general tilney children]2485-his children , and detesting old chests ; and [the General]2216-the general , recovering [his]2216-the general politeness as [he]2216-the general looked at [her]1284-the wretched matilda , spent the rest of [his]2216-the general time in scolding [[his]2216-the general daughter]598-his daughter for so foolishly hurrying [[her]1284-the wretched matilda fair friend]1922-her fair friend , who was absolutely out of breath from haste , when there was not the least occasion for hurry in [the world]215-the world : but [Catherine]76-catherine could not at all get over the double distress of having involved [[her]1284-the wretched matilda friend]1769-her friend in a lecture and been [a great simpleton]2699-a great simpleton [herself]76-catherine , till [they]2690-they were happily seated at the dinner - table , when [the General]2216-the general ’s complacent smiles , and a good appetite of [her]1284-the wretched matilda own , restored [her]1284-the wretched matilda to peace . [The dining - parlour]2701-the dining - parlour was [a noble room , suitable in [its]2701-the dining - parlour dimensions to [a much larger drawing - room than [the one in common use]2704-the one in common use]2703-a much larger drawing - room than the one in common use]2702-a noble room , suitable in its dimensions to a much larger drawing - room than the one in common use [, and fitted up in a style of luxury and expense which was almost lost on the unpractised eye of [Catherine]76-catherine , who saw little more than [its]2701-the dining - parlour spaciousness and the number of [[their]2690-they attendants]2706-their attendants]2705-, and fitted up in a style of luxury and expense which was almost lost on the unpractised eye of catherine , who saw little more than its spaciousness and the number of their attendants . Of [the former]2038-the former , [she]1284-the wretched matilda spoke aloud [her]1284-the wretched matilda admiration ; and [the General]2216-the general , with a very gracious countenance , acknowledged that [it]2701-the dining - parlour was by no means [an ill - sized room]2709-an ill - sized room , and further confessed that , though as careless on such subjects as [most people]2710-most people , [he]2216-the general did look upon [a tolerably large eating - room]2711-a tolerably large eating - room as one of the necessaries of life ; [he]2216-the general supposed , however , “[1287-she] that [she]1287-she must have been used to [much better - sized apartments at [Mr. Allen ’s]85-mr. allen]1288-much better - sized apartments at mr. allen ’s ? ” “[1287-she] No , indeed , ” was [Catherine]76-catherine ’s honest assurance ; “[1287-she] [[Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s dining - parlour]1289-mr. allen ’s dining - parlour was not more than half as large , ” and [she]1284-the wretched matilda had never seen so large [a room]1258-a room as this in [her]1284-the wretched matilda life . [The General]2216-the general ’s good humour increased . Why , as [he]2216-the general _ had _ [such rooms]2714-such rooms , [he]2216-the general thought it would be simple not to make use of [them]2714-such rooms ; but , upon [his]2216-the general honour , [he]2216-the general believed there might be more comfort in [rooms of only half [their]2714-such rooms size]2715-rooms of only half their size . [[Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s house]1889-mr. allen ’s house , [he]2216-the general was sure , must be exactly of the true size for rational happiness . The evening passed without any further disturbance , and , in the occasional absence of [General Tilney]139-general tilney , with much positive cheerfulness . It was only in [his]2216-the general presence that [Catherine]76-catherine felt the smallest fatigue from [her]1284-the wretched matilda journey ; and even then , even in moments of languor or restraint , a sense of general happiness preponderated , and [she]1284-the wretched matilda could think of [[her]1284-the wretched matilda friends]2225-her friends in [Bath]1824-bath without one wish of being with [them]2225-her friends . The night was stormy ; the wind had been rising at intervals the whole afternoon ; and by the time the party broke up , it blew and rained violently . [Catherine]76-catherine , as [she]1284-the wretched matilda crossed [the hall]2659-the hall , listened to the tempest with sensations of awe ; and , when [she]1284-the wretched matilda heard it rage round a corner of [the ancient building]2561-the ancient building and close with sudden fury a distant door , felt for the first time that [she]1284-the wretched matilda was really in [an abbey]2540-an abbey . Yes , these were characteristic sounds ; they brought to [her]1284-the wretched matilda recollection a countless variety of dreadful situations and horrid scenes , which [such buildings]2722-such buildings had witnessed , and such storms ushered in ; and most heartily did [she]1284-the wretched matilda rejoice in the happier circumstances attending [her]1284-the wretched matilda entrance within walls so solemn ! _ [She]1284-the wretched matilda _ had nothing to dread from [midnight assassins]2723-midnight assassins or [drunken gallants]2724-drunken gallants . [Henry]95-henry had certainly been only in jest in what [he]95-henry had told [her]1284-the wretched matilda that morning . In [a house so furnished]2725-a house so furnished , and so guarded , [she]1284-the wretched matilda could have nothing to explore or to suffer , and might go to [[her]1284-the wretched matilda bedroom]2726-her bedroom as securely as if it had been [[her]1284-the wretched matilda own chamber at [Fullerton]4-fullerton]2727-her own chamber at fullerton . Thus wisely fortifying [her]1284-the wretched matilda mind , as [she]1284-the wretched matilda proceeded [upstairs]1893-upstairs , [she]1284-the wretched matilda was enabled , especially on perceiving that [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney slept only two doors from [her]1284-the wretched matilda , to enter [[her]1284-the wretched matilda room]2729-her room with a tolerably stout heart ; and [her]1284-the wretched matilda spirits were immediately assisted by the cheerful blaze of a wood fire . “[85-mr. allen] How much better is this , ” said [she]1284-the wretched matilda , as [she]1284-the wretched matilda walked to the fender—“how[1287-she] much better to find a fire ready lit , than to have to wait shivering in the cold till all [the family]1904-the family are in bed , as [so many poor girls]1291-so many poor girls have been obliged to do , and then to have [a faithful old servant]1292-a faithful old servant frightening [one]305-one by coming in with a faggot ! how glad [I]0-i am that [Northanger]62-northanger is what it is ! if it had been like [some other places]1294-some other places , [I]0-i do not know that , in such a night as this , [I]0-i could have answered for [my]0-i courage : but now , to be sure , there is nothing to alarm [one]305-one . ” [She]1284-the wretched matilda looked round [the room]1765-the room . The window curtains seemed in motion . It could be nothing but the violence of the wind penetrating through the divisions of the shutters ; and [she]1284-the wretched matilda stepped boldly forward , carelessly humming a tune , to assure [herself]1284-the wretched matilda of its being so , peeped courageously behind each curtain , saw nothing on either low window seat to scare [her]1284-the wretched matilda , and on placing a hand against the shutter , felt the strongest conviction of the wind ’s force . A glance at the old chest , as [she]1284-the wretched matilda turned away from this examination , was not without its use ; [she]1284-the wretched matilda scorned the causeless fears of an idle fancy , and began with a most happy indifference to prepare [herself]1284-the wretched matilda for bed . “[1296-she] [She]1296-she should take [her]1296-she time ; [she]1296-she should not hurry [herself]1296-she ; [she]1296-she did not care if [she]1296-she were [the last person up in [the house]238-the house]1297-the last person up in the house . But [she]1296-she would not make up [her]1296-she fire ; _ that _ would seem cowardly , as if [she]1296-she wished for the protection of light after [she]1296-she were in bed . ” The fire therefore died away , and [Catherine]76-catherine , having spent the best part of an hour in [her]1284-the wretched matilda arrangements , was beginning to think of stepping into bed , when , on giving a parting glance round [the room]1765-the room , [she]1284-the wretched matilda was struck by the appearance of a high , old - fashioned black cabinet , which , though in a situation conspicuous enough , had never caught [her]1284-the wretched matilda notice before . [Henry]95-henry ’s words , [his]95-henry description of the ebony cabinet which was to escape [her]1284-the wretched matilda observation at first , immediately rushed across [her]1284-the wretched matilda ; and though there could be nothing really in it , there was something whimsical , it was certainly a very remarkable coincidence ! [She]1284-the wretched matilda took [her]1284-the wretched matilda candle and looked closely at the cabinet . It was not absolutely ebony and gold ; but it was japan , black and yellow japan of the handsomest kind ; and as [she]1284-the wretched matilda held [her]1284-the wretched matilda candle , the yellow had very much the effect of gold . The key was in the door , and [she]1284-the wretched matilda had a strange fancy to look into it ; not , however , with the smallest expectation of finding anything , but it was so very odd , after what [Henry]95-henry had said . In short , [she]1284-the wretched matilda could not sleep till [she]1284-the wretched matilda had examined it . So , placing the candle with great caution on a chair , [she]1284-the wretched matilda seized the key with a very tremulous hand and tried to turn it ; but it resisted [her]1284-the wretched matilda utmost strength . Alarmed , but not discouraged , [she]1284-the wretched matilda tried it another way ; a bolt flew , and [she]1284-the wretched matilda believed [herself]1284-the wretched matilda successful ; but how strangely mysterious ! the door was still immovable . [She]1284-the wretched matilda paused a moment in breathless wonder . The wind roared down the chimney , the rain beat in torrents against the windows , and everything seemed to speak the awfulness of [her]1284-the wretched matilda situation . To retire to bed , however , unsatisfied on such a point , would be vain , since sleep must be impossible with the consciousness of a cabinet so mysteriously closed in [her]1284-the wretched matilda immediate vicinity . Again , therefore , [she]1284-the wretched matilda applied [herself]1284-the wretched matilda to the key , and after moving it in every possible way for some instants with the determined celerity of hope ’s last effort , the door suddenly yielded to [her]1284-the wretched matilda hand : [her]1284-the wretched matilda heart leaped with exultation at such a victory , and having thrown open each folding door , the second being secured only by bolts of less wonderful construction than the lock , though in that [her]1284-the wretched matilda eye could not discern anything unusual , a double range of small drawers appeared in view , with some larger drawers above and below [them]2732-them ; and in the centre , a small door , closed also with a lock and key , secured in all probability a cavity of importance . [Catherine]76-catherine ’s heart beat quick , but [her]1284-the wretched matilda courage did not fail [her]1284-the wretched matilda . With a cheek flushed by hope , and an eye straining with curiosity , [her]1284-the wretched matilda fingers grasped the handle of a drawer and drew it forth . It was entirely empty . With less alarm and greater eagerness [she]1284-the wretched matilda seized a second , a third , a fourth ; each was equally empty . Not one was left unsearched , and in not one was anything found . Well read in the art of concealing a treasure , the possibility of false linings to the drawers did not escape [her]1284-the wretched matilda , and [she]1284-the wretched matilda felt round each with anxious acuteness in vain . The place in the middle alone remained now unexplored ; and though [she]1284-the wretched matilda had “[1296-she] never from the first had the smallest idea of finding anything in any part of the cabinet , and was not in the least disappointed at [her]1299-her ill success thus far , it would be foolish not to examine it thoroughly while [she]1299-her was about it . ” It was some time however before [she]1284-the wretched matilda could unfasten the door , the same difficulty occurring in the management of this inner lock as of the outer ; but at length it did open ; and not vain , as hitherto , was [her]1284-the wretched matilda search ; [her]1284-the wretched matilda quick eyes directly fell on a roll of paper pushed back into the further part of the cavity , apparently for concealment , and [her]1284-the wretched matilda feelings at that moment were indescribable . [Her]1284-the wretched matilda heart fluttered , [her]1284-the wretched matilda knees trembled , and [her]1284-the wretched matilda cheeks grew pale . [She]1284-the wretched matilda seized , with an unsteady hand , the precious manuscript , for half a glance sufficed to ascertain written characters ; and while [she]1284-the wretched matilda acknowledged with awful sensations this striking exemplification of what [Henry]95-henry had foretold , resolved instantly to peruse every line before [she]1284-the wretched matilda attempted to rest . The dimness of the light [her]1284-the wretched matilda candle emitted made [her]1284-the wretched matilda turn to it with alarm ; but there was no danger of its sudden extinction ; it had yet some hours to burn ; and that [she]1284-the wretched matilda might not have any greater difficulty in distinguishing the writing than what its ancient date might occasion , [she]1284-the wretched matilda hastily snuffed it . Alas ! it was snuffed and extinguished in one . A lamp could not have expired with more awful effect . [Catherine]76-catherine , for a few moments , was motionless with horror . It was done completely ; not a remnant of light in the wick could give hope to the rekindling breath . Darkness impenetrable and immovable filled [the room]1765-the room . A violent gust of wind , rising with sudden fury , added fresh horror to the moment . [Catherine]76-catherine trembled from head to foot . In the pause which succeeded , a sound like receding footsteps and the closing of a distant door struck on [her]1284-the wretched matilda affrighted ear . Human nature could support no more . A cold sweat stood on [her]1284-the wretched matilda forehead , the manuscript fell from [her]1284-the wretched matilda hand , and groping [her]1284-the wretched matilda way to the bed , [she]1284-the wretched matilda jumped hastily in , and sought some suspension of agony by creeping far underneath the clothes . To close [her]1284-the wretched matilda eyes in sleep that night , [she]1284-the wretched matilda felt must be entirely out of the question . With a curiosity so justly awakened , and feelings in every way so agitated , repose must be absolutely impossible . The storm too abroad so dreadful ! [she]1284-the wretched matilda had not been used to feel alarm from wind , but now every blast seemed fraught with awful intelligence . The manuscript so wonderfully found , so wonderfully accomplishing the morning ’s prediction , how was it to be accounted for ? What could it contain ? To whom could it relate ? By what means could it have been so long concealed ? And how singularly strange that it should fall to [her]1284-the wretched matilda lot to discover it ! till [she]1284-the wretched matilda had made [herself]1284-the wretched matilda mistress of its contents , however , [she]1284-the wretched matilda could have neither repose nor comfort ; and with the sun ’s first rays [she]1284-the wretched matilda was determined to peruse it . But many were the tedious hours which must yet intervene . [She]1284-the wretched matilda shuddered , tossed about in [her]1284-the wretched matilda bed , and envied [every quiet sleeper]2734-every quiet sleeper . The storm still raged , and various were the noises , more terrific even than the wind , which struck at intervals on [her]1284-the wretched matilda startled ear . The very curtains of [her]1284-the wretched matilda bed seemed at one moment in motion , and at another the lock of [her]1284-the wretched matilda door was agitated , as if by the attempt of [somebody]264-somebody to enter . Hollow murmurs seemed to creep along [the gallery]2736-the gallery , and more than once [her]1284-the wretched matilda blood was chilled by the sound of distant moans . Hour after hour passed away , and [the wearied Catherine]2737-the wearied catherine had heard three proclaimed by all the clocks in [the house]238-the house before the tempest subsided or [she]2737-the wearied catherine unknowingly fell fast asleep . CHAPTER 22 [The housemaid]2739-the housemaid ’s folding back [her]2739-the housemaid window - shutters at eight o’clock the next day was the sound which first roused [Catherine]76-catherine ; and [she]2737-the wearied catherine opened [her]2737-the wearied catherine eyes , wondering that they could ever have been closed , on objects of cheerfulness ; [her]2739-the housemaid fire was already burning , and a bright morning had succeeded the tempest of the night . Instantaneously , with the consciousness of existence , returned [her]1284-the wretched matilda recollection of the manuscript ; and springing from the bed in the very moment of [the maid]2740-the maid ’s going away , [she]1284-the wretched matilda eagerly collected every scattered sheet which had burst from the roll on its falling to the ground , and flew back to enjoy the luxury of their perusal on [her]1284-the wretched matilda pillow . [She]1284-the wretched matilda now plainly saw that [she]1284-the wretched matilda must not expect a manuscript of equal length with the generality of what [she]1284-the wretched matilda had shuddered over in books , for the roll , seeming to consist entirely of small disjointed sheets , was altogether but of trifling size , and much less than [she]1284-the wretched matilda had supposed it to be at first . [Her]1284-the wretched matilda greedy eye glanced rapidly over a page . [She]1284-the wretched matilda started at its import . Could it be possible , or did not [her]1284-the wretched matilda senses play [her]1284-the wretched matilda false ? An inventory of linen , in coarse and modern characters , seemed all that was before [her]1284-the wretched matilda ! if the evidence of sight might be trusted , [she]1284-the wretched matilda held a washing - bill in [her]1284-the wretched matilda hand . [She]1284-the wretched matilda seized another sheet , and saw the same articles with little variation ; a third , a fourth , and a fifth presented nothing new . Shirts , stockings , cravats , and waistcoats faced [her]1284-the wretched matilda in each . [Two others , penned by the same hand]2741-two others , penned by the same hand , marked an expenditure scarcely more interesting , in letters , hair - powder , shoe - string , and breeches - ball . And the larger sheet , which had enclosed the rest , seemed by its first cramp line , “[325-your sister] To poultice chestnut mare”—a farrier ’s bill ! such was the collection of papers ( left perhaps , as [she]1284-the wretched matilda could then suppose , by the negligence of [a servant in the place whence [she]1284-the wretched matilda had taken them]2742-a servant in the place whence she had taken them ) which had filled [her]1284-the wretched matilda with expectation and alarm , and robbed [her]1284-the wretched matilda of half [her]1284-the wretched matilda night ’s rest ! [she]1284-the wretched matilda felt humbled to the dust . Could not the adventure of the chest have taught [her]1284-the wretched matilda wisdom ? A corner of it , catching [her]1284-the wretched matilda eye as [she]1284-the wretched matilda lay , seemed to rise up in judgment against [her]1284-the wretched matilda . Nothing could now be clearer than the absurdity of [her]1284-the wretched matilda recent fancies . To suppose that a manuscript of many generations back could have remained undiscovered in [a room such as that , so modern , so habitable!—Or that [she]1284-the wretched matilda should be the first to possess the skill of unlocking a cabinet , the key of which was open to all]2743-a room such as that , so modern , so habitable!—or that she should be the first to possess the skill of unlocking a cabinet , the key of which was open to all ! How could [she]1284-the wretched matilda have so imposed on [herself]1284-the wretched matilda ? Heaven forbid that [Henry Tilney]95-henry should ever know [her]1284-the wretched matilda folly ! and it was in a great measure [his]95-henry own doing , for had not the cabinet appeared so exactly to agree with [his]95-henry description of [her]1284-the wretched matilda adventures , [she]1284-the wretched matilda should never have felt the smallest curiosity about it . This was the only comfort that occurred . Impatient to get rid of those hateful evidences of [her]1284-the wretched matilda folly , those detestable papers then scattered over the bed , [she]1284-the wretched matilda rose directly , and folding them up as nearly as possible in the same shape as before , returned them to the same spot within the cabinet , with a very hearty wish that no untoward accident might ever bring them forward again , to disgrace [her]1284-the wretched matilda even with [herself]1284-the wretched matilda . Why the locks should have been so difficult to open , however , was still something remarkable , for [she]1284-the wretched matilda could now manage them with perfect ease . In this there was surely something mysterious , and [she]1284-the wretched matilda indulged in the flattering suggestion for half a minute , till the possibility of the door ’s having been at first unlocked , and of being [herself]1284-the wretched matilda its fastener , darted into [her]1284-the wretched matilda head , and cost [her]1284-the wretched matilda another blush . [She]1284-the wretched matilda got away as soon as [she]1284-the wretched matilda could from [a room in which [her]1284-the wretched matilda conduct produced such unpleasant reflections]2744-a room in which her conduct produced such unpleasant reflections , and found [her]1284-the wretched matilda way with all speed to [the breakfast - parlour]2745-the breakfast - parlour , as it had been pointed out to [her]1284-the wretched matilda by [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney the evening before . [Henry]95-henry was alone in [it]2745-the breakfast - parlour ; and [his]95-henry immediate hope of [her]1284-the wretched matilda having been undisturbed by the tempest , with an arch reference to the character of [the building]2650-the building [they]1300-they inhabited , was rather distressing . For [the world]215-the world would [she]1284-the wretched matilda not have [her]1284-the wretched matilda weakness suspected , and yet , unequal to an absolute falsehood , was constrained to acknowledge that the wind had kept [her]1284-the wretched matilda awake a little . “[325-your sister] But [we]1300-they have a charming morning after it , ” [she]1284-the wretched matilda added , desiring to get rid of the subject ; “[1300-they] and storms and sleeplessness are nothing when they are over . What beautiful hyacinths ! [i]0-i have just learnt to love a hyacinth . ” “[0-i] And how might [you]0-i learn ? By accident or argument ? ” “[0-i] [[Your]0-i sister]325-your sister taught [me]0-i ; [I]0-i can not tell how . [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen used to take pains , year after year , to make [me]0-i like them ; but [I]0-i never could , till [I]0-i saw [them]1302-them the other day in [Milsom Street]15-milsom street ; [I]0-i am naturally indifferent about flowers . ” “[88-mrs. allen] But now [you]0-i love a hyacinth . So much the better . [You]0-i have gained a new source of enjoyment , and it is well to have as many holds upon happiness as possible . Besides , a taste for flowers is always desirable in [your]0-i sex , as a means of getting [you]0-i out of doors , and tempting [you]0-i to more frequent exercise than [you]0-i would otherwise take . And though the love of [a hyacinth]1303-a hyacinth may be rather domestic , who can tell , the sentiment once raised , but [you]0-i may in time come to love a rose ? ” “[138-mamma] But [I]0-i do not want any such pursuit to get [me]0-i out of doors . The pleasure of walking and breathing fresh air is enough for [me]0-i , and in fine weather [I]0-i am out more than half [my]0-i time . [Mamma]138-mamma says [I]0-i am never within . ” “[138-mamma] At any rate , however , [I]0-i am pleased that [you]0-i have learnt to love a hyacinth . The mere habit of learning to love is the thing ; and a teachableness of disposition in [a young lady]1707-a young lady is a great blessing . Has [[my]0-i sister]322-my sister a pleasant mode of instruction ? ” [Catherine]76-catherine was saved the embarrassment of attempting an answer by the entrance of [the General , whose smiling compliments announced a happy state of mind]2748-the general , whose smiling compliments announced a happy state of mind , but whose gentle hint of sympathetic early rising did not advance [her]322-my sister composure . The elegance of the breakfast set forced itself on [Catherine]76-catherine ’s notice when [they]2749-they were seated at table ; and , luckily , it had been [the General]2216-the general ’s choice . [He]2216-the general was enchanted by [her]322-my sister approbation of [his]2216-the general taste , confessed it to be neat and simple , thought it right to encourage the manufacture of [[his]2216-the general country]2751-his country ; and for [his]2216-the general part , to [his]2216-the general uncritical palate , the tea was as well flavoured from the clay of [Staffordshire]66-staffordshire , as from that of [Dresden]167-dresden or [Sêve]168-sêve . But this was quite an old set , purchased two years ago . The manufacture was much improved since that time ; [he]2216-the general had seen some beautiful specimens when last in [town]427-town , and had [he]2216-the general not been perfectly without vanity of that kind , might have been tempted to order a new set . [He]2216-the general trusted , however , that an opportunity might ere long occur of selecting one — though not for [himself]2216-the general . [Catherine]76-catherine was probably [the only one of the party who did not understand [him]2216-the general]2753-the only one of the party who did not understand him . Shortly after breakfast [Henry]95-henry left [them]2754-them for [Woodston]64-woodston , where business required and would keep [him]95-henry two or three days . [They]2754-them all attended in [the hall]2659-the hall to see [him]95-henry mount [his]95-henry horse , and immediately on re - entering [the breakfast - room]2756-the breakfast - room , [Catherine]76-catherine walked to a window in the hope of catching another glimpse of [his]95-henry figure . “[322-my sister] This is a somewhat heavy call upon [[your]1306-you brother]474-your brother ’s fortitude , ” observed [the General]2216-the general to [Eleanor]143-eleanor . “[322-my sister] [Woodston]64-woodston will make but a sombre appearance to - day . ” “[322-my sister] Is [it]64-woodston [a pretty place]1308-a pretty place ? ” asked [Catherine]76-catherine . “[322-my sister] What say [you]1306-you , [Eleanor]143-eleanor ? Speak [your]1306-you opinion , for [ladies]310-ladies can best tell the taste of [ladies]310-ladies in regard to places as well as [men]316-men . [I]0-i think it would be acknowledged by the most impartial eye to have many recommendations . [The house]238-the house stands among fine meadows facing [the south - east]1313-the south - east , with an excellent [kitchen - garden in the same aspect]1314-kitchen - garden in the same aspect ; the walls surrounding which [I]0-i built and stocked [myself]0-i about ten years ago , for the benefit of [[my]0-i son]1315-my son . It is a family living , [Miss Morland]86-miss morland ; and [the property in [the place]284-the place]1316-the property in the place being chiefly [my]0-i own , [you]1306-you may believe [I]0-i take care that it shall not be a bad one . Did [Henry]95-henry ’s income depend solely on this living , [he]95-henry would not be ill - provided for . Perhaps it may seem odd , that with [only two younger children]1318-only two younger children , [I]0-i should think any profession necessary for [him]95-henry ; and certainly there are moments when [we]1319-we could all wish [him]95-henry disengaged from every tie of business . Something had been said the evening before of [her]1834-the lady being shown over [the house]238-the house , and [he]0-i now offered [himself]0-i as [[her]1834-the lady conductor]2760-her conductor ; and though [Catherine]76-catherine had hoped to explore [it]238-the house accompanied only by [[his]0-i daughter]598-his daughter , it was a proposal of too much happiness in itself , under any circumstances , not to be gladly accepted ; for [she]1834-the lady had been already eighteen hours in [the abbey]1248-the abbey , and had seen only a few of [[its]1248-the abbey rooms]2763-its rooms . The netting - box , just leisurely drawn forth , was closed with joyful haste , and [she]1834-the lady was ready to attend [him]1329-he in a moment . “[1329-he] And when [they]1327-they had gone over [the house]238-the house , [he]1329-he promised [himself]1329-he moreover the pleasure of accompanying [her]1330-her into [the shrubberies]1331-the shrubberies and [garden]1332-garden . ” [She]1834-the lady curtsied [her]1834-the lady acquiescence . “[1329-he] But perhaps it might be more agreeable to [her]1330-her to make those [her]1330-her first object . The weather was at present favourable , and at this time of year the uncertainty was very great of its continuing so . Which would [she]1330-her prefer ? [He]1329-he was equally at [her]1330-her service . Which did [[his]1329-he daughter]598-his daughter think would most accord with [[her]598-his daughter fair friend]1922-her fair friend ’s wishes ? But when did [she]1330-her judge amiss ? [The abbey]1248-the abbey would be always safe and dry . [He]1329-he yielded implicitly , and would fetch [his]1329-he hat and attend [them]1336-them in a moment . ” [He]1329-he left [the room]1765-the room , and [Catherine]76-catherine , with a disappointed , anxious face , began to speak of [her]1330-her unwillingness that [he]1329-he should be taking them out of doors against [his]1329-he own inclination , under a mistaken idea of pleasing [her]1330-her ; but [she]1330-her was stopped by [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney ’s saying , with a little confusion , “[1329-he] [I]0-i believe it will be wisest to take the morning while it is so fine ; and do not be uneasy on [[my]0-i father]629-my father ’s account ; [he]1329-he always walks out at this time of day . ” [Catherine]76-catherine did not exactly know how this was to be understood . Why was [Miss Tilney]92-miss tilney embarrassed ? Could there be any unwillingness on [the General]2216-the general ’s side to show [her]1330-her over [the abbey]1248-the abbey ? The proposal was [his]1329-he own . And was not it odd that [he]1329-he should _ always _ take [his]1329-he walk so early ? Neither [[her]1330-her father]205-her father nor [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen did so . It was certainly very provoking . [She]1330-her was all impatience to see [the house]238-the house , and had scarcely any curiosity about [the grounds]2769-the grounds . If [Henry]95-henry had been with [them]2769-the grounds indeed ! But now [she]1330-her should not know what was picturesque when [she]1330-her saw it . Such were [her]1330-her thoughts , but [she]1330-her kept them to [herself]1330-her , and put on [her]1330-her bonnet in patient discontent . [She]1330-her was struck , however , beyond [her]1330-her expectation , by the grandeur of [the abbey]1248-the abbey , as [she]1330-her saw [it]1248-the abbey for the first time from [the lawn]2771-the lawn . [The whole building]2772-the whole building enclosed [a large court]2773-a large court ; and two sides of [the quadrangle]2774-the quadrangle , rich in Gothic ornaments , stood forward for admiration . [The remainder]1801-the remainder was shut off by knolls of old trees , or [luxuriant plantations]2776-luxuriant plantations , and [the steep woody hills]2777-the steep woody hills rising behind , to give [it]1801-the remainder shelter , were beautiful even in the leafless month of March . [Catherine]76-catherine had seen nothing to compare with it ; and [her]1330-her feelings of delight were so strong , that without waiting for any better authority , [she]1330-her boldly burst forth in wonder and praise . [The General]2216-the general listened with assenting gratitude ; and it seemed as if [his]2216-the general own estimation of [Northanger]62-northanger had waited unfixed till that hour . [The kitchen - garden]2779-the kitchen - garden was to be next admired , and [he]2216-the general led the way to [it]2779-the kitchen - garden across [a small portion of [the park]2781-the park]2780-a small portion of the park . The number of acres contained in [this garden]2782-this garden was such as [Catherine]76-catherine could not listen to without dismay , being more than double the extent of all [Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s , as well as [[her]1330-her father]205-her father ’s , including [church - yard]2784-church - yard and [orchard]2785-orchard . [The walls]2786-the walls seemed countless in number , endless in length ; [a village of [hot - houses]2788-hot - houses]2787-a village of hot - houses seemed to arise among [them]2786-the walls , and [a whole parish]2789-a whole parish to be at work within [the enclosure]2790-the enclosure . [The General]2216-the general was flattered by [her]1330-her looks of surprise , which told [him]2216-the general almost as plainly , as [he]2216-the general soon forced [her]1330-her to tell [him]2216-the general in words , that [she]1330-her had never seen [any gardens]2792-any gardens at all equal to [them]1339-them before ; and [he]2216-the general then modestly owned that , “[1338-he] without any ambition of that sort [himself]1338-he — without any solicitude about it — [he]1338-he did believe [them]1339-them to be unrivalled in [the kingdom]760-the kingdom . If [he]1338-he had a hobby - horse , it was _ that _ . [He]1338-he loved [a garden]223-a garden . Though careless enough in most matters of eating , [he]1338-he loved good fruit — or if [he]1338-he did not , [[his]1338-he friends]1342-his friends and [children]1706-children did . There were great vexations , however , attending [such a garden as [his]1338-he]1344-such a garden as his . The utmost care could not always secure the most valuable fruits . [The pinery]1345-the pinery had yielded only one hundred in the last year . [He]2216-the general perceived [her]86-miss morland inclination , and having again urged the plea of health in vain , was too polite to make further opposition . [He]1356-he excused [himself]1356-he , however , from attending [them]1357-them : “[1357-them] The rays of the sun were not too cheerful for [him]1356-he , and [he]1356-he would meet [them]1357-them by another course . ” [He]1356-he turned away ; and [Catherine]76-catherine was shocked to find how much [her]86-miss morland spirits were relieved by the separation . The shock , however , being less real than the relief , offered it no injury ; and [she]86-miss morland began to talk with easy gaiety of the delightful melancholy which [such a grove]2800-such a grove inspired . “[0-i] [I]0-i am particularly fond of this spot , ” said [[her]86-miss morland companion]2014-her companion , with a sigh . “[0-i] It was [[my]0-i mother]607-my mother ’s favourite walk . ” [Catherine]76-catherine had never heard [Mrs. Tilney]129-mrs. tilney mentioned in [the family]1904-the family before , and the interest excited by this tender remembrance showed itself directly in [her]86-miss morland altered countenance , and in the attentive pause with which [she]86-miss morland waited for something more . “[607-my mother] [I]0-i used to walk [here]1743-here so often with [her]607-my mother ! ” added [Eleanor]143-eleanor ; “[0-i] though [I]0-i never loved it then , as [I]0-i have loved it since .
