A more considerable degree of wandering attended the third repetition ; and , after completing the fourth , [she]3344-she immediately added , “[2216-the general] Only think , [[my]0-i dear]253-my dear , of [my]0-i having got that frightful great rent in [my]0-i best Mechlin so charmingly mended , before [I]0-i left [Bath]6-bath , that [one]305-one can hardly see where it was . [I]0-i must show it [you]253-my dear some day or other . [Bath]1824-bath is [a nice place]1634-a nice place , [Catherine]76-catherine , after all . [I]0-i assure [you]253-my dear [I]0-i did not above half like coming away . [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe ’s being [there]1848-there was such a comfort to [us]1636-us , was not it ? [You]253-my dear know , [you]253-my dear and [I]0-i were quite forlorn at first . ” “[253-my dear] Yes , but _ that _ did not last long , ” said [Catherine]76-catherine , [her]253-my dear eyes brightening at the recollection of what had first given spirit to [her]253-my dear existence there . “[253-my dear] Very true : [we]1636-us soon met with [Mrs. Thorpe]98-mrs. thorpe , and then [we]1636-us wanted for nothing . [[My]0-i dear]253-my dear , do not [you]253-my dear think these silk gloves wear very well ? [I]0-i put them on new the first time of [our]1636-us going to [the Lower Rooms]1826-the lower rooms , [you]253-my dear know , and [I]0-i have worn them a great deal since . Do [you]253-my dear remember that evening ? ” “[253-my dear] Do [I]0-i ! oh ! perfectly . ” “[0-i] It was very agreeable , was not it ? [Mr. Tilney]95-henry drank tea with [us]1636-us , and [I]0-i always thought [him]95-henry a great addition , [he]95-henry is so very agreeable . [I]0-i have a notion [you]253-my dear danced with [him]95-henry , but am not quite sure . [I]0-i remember [I]0-i had [my]0-i favourite gown on . ” [Catherine]76-catherine could not answer ; and , after a short trial of other subjects , [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen again returned to—“I[1641-an agreeable , worthy man] really have not patience with [the General]2216-the general ! [such [an agreeable , worthy man]1641-an agreeable , worthy man as [he]95-henry seemed to be]1640-such an agreeable , worthy man as he seemed to be ! [i]0-i do not suppose , [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland , [you]253-my dear ever saw [a better - bred man in [your]253-my dear life]1642-a better - bred man in your life . [[His]1642-a better - bred man in your life lodgings]1643-his lodgings were taken the very day after [he]1642-a better - bred man in your life left [them]1643-his lodgings , [Catherine]76-catherine . But no wonder ; [Milsom Street]15-milsom street , [you]253-my dear know . ” As [they]3345-they walked [home]482-home again , [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland endeavoured to impress on [[her]80-mrs. morland daughter]1729-her daughter ’s mind the happiness of having [such steady well - wishers as [Mr.]3349-mr. and [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen]3348-such steady well - wishers as mr. and mrs. allen , and the very little consideration which the neglect or unkindness of slight acquaintance like [the Tilneys]133-the tilneys ought to have with [her]1729-her daughter , while [she]1729-her daughter could preserve the good opinion and affection of [[her]1729-her daughter earliest friends]3350-her earliest friends . There was a great deal of good sense in all this ; but there are some situations of the human mind in which good sense has very little power ; and [Catherine]76-catherine ’s feelings contradicted almost every position [[her]1729-her daughter mother]211-her mother advanced . It was upon the behaviour of [these very slight acquaintance]3352-these very slight acquaintance that all [her]1729-her daughter present happiness depended ; and while [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland was successfully confirming [her]80-mrs. morland own opinions by the justness of [her]80-mrs. morland own representations , [Catherine]76-catherine was silently reflecting that _ now _ [Henry]95-henry must have arrived at [Northanger]62-northanger ; _ now _ [he]95-henry must have heard of [her]1729-her daughter departure ; and _ now _ , perhaps , [they]3353-they were all setting off for [Hereford]72-hereford . CHAPTER 30 [Catherine]76-catherine ’s disposition was not naturally sedentary , nor had [her]1729-her daughter habits been ever very industrious ; but whatever might hitherto have been [her]1729-her daughter defects of that sort , [[her]1729-her daughter mother]211-her mother could not but perceive them now to be greatly increased . [She]1729-her daughter could neither sit still nor employ [herself]1729-her daughter for ten minutes together , walking round [the garden]1346-the garden and [orchard]2785-orchard again and again , as if nothing but motion was voluntary ; and it seemed as if [she]1729-her daughter could even walk about [the house]238-the house rather than remain fixed for any time in the parlour . [Her]1729-her daughter loss of spirits was a yet greater alteration . In [her]1729-her daughter rambling and [her]1729-her daughter idleness [she]1729-her daughter might only be a caricature of [herself]1729-her daughter ; but in [her]1729-her daughter silence and sadness [she]1729-her daughter was the very reverse of all that [she]1729-her daughter had been before . For two days [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland allowed it to pass even without a hint ; but when a third night ’s rest had neither restored [her]1729-her daughter cheerfulness , improved [her]1729-her daughter in useful activity , nor given [her]1729-her daughter a greater inclination for needlework , [she]1729-her daughter could no longer refrain from the gentle reproof of , “[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]253-my dear [Catherine]76-catherine , [I]0-i am afraid [you]76-catherine are growing quite [a fine lady]1645-a fine lady . [I]0-i do not know when poor [Richard]77-captain tilney ’s cravats would be done , if [he]77-captain tilney had [no friend]1618-no friend but [you]76-catherine . [Your]76-catherine head runs too much upon Bath ; but there is a time for everything — a time for balls and plays , and a time for work . [You]76-catherine have had a long run of amusement , and now [you]76-catherine must try to be useful . ” [Catherine]76-catherine took up [her]1002-my catherine work directly , saying , in a dejected voice , that “[1647-her] [her]1647-her head did not run upon [Bath]1824-bath — much . ” “[1647-her] Then [you]76-catherine are fretting about [General Tilney]139-general tilney , and that is very simple of [you]76-catherine ; for ten to one whether [you]76-catherine ever see [him]139-general tilney again . [You]76-catherine should never fret about trifles . ” After a short silence—“I[76-catherine] hope , [[my]0-i [Catherine]76-catherine]1002-my catherine , [you]76-catherine are not getting out of humour with [home]482-home because it is not so grand as [Northanger]62-northanger . That would be turning [your]76-catherine visit into an evil indeed . Wherever [you]76-catherine are [you]76-catherine should always be contented , but especially at [home]482-home , because there [you]76-catherine must spend the most of [your]76-catherine time . [I]0-i did not quite like , at breakfast , to hear [you]76-catherine talk so much about the French bread at [Northanger]62-northanger . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i do not care about the bread . It is all the same to [me]0-i what [I]0-i eat . ” “[0-i] There is a very clever essay in one of the books [upstairs]1893-upstairs upon much such a subject , about [young girls that have been spoilt for home by great acquaintance]1653-young girls that have been spoilt for home by great acquaintance — The Mirror , [I]0-i think . [I]0-i will look it out for [you]76-catherine some day or other , because [I]0-i am sure it will do [you]76-catherine good . ” [Catherine]76-catherine said no more , and , with an endeavour to do right , applied to [her]3358-her work ; but , after a few minutes , sunk again , without knowing it [herself]3358-her , into languor and listlessness , moving [herself]3358-her in [her]3358-her chair , from the irritation of weariness , much oftener than [she]3358-her moved [her]3358-her needle . [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland watched the progress of this relapse ; and seeing , in [[her]80-mrs. morland daughter]1729-her daughter ’s absent and dissatisfied look , the full proof of that repining spirit to which [she]80-mrs. morland had now begun to attribute [her]80-mrs. morland want of cheerfulness , hastily left [the room]1765-the room to fetch the book in question , anxious to lose no time in attacking so dreadful a malady . It was some time before [she]80-mrs. morland could find what [she]80-mrs. morland looked for ; and other family matters occurring to detain [her]80-mrs. morland , a quarter of an hour had elapsed ere [she]80-mrs. morland returned [downstairs]2119-downstairs with the volume from which so much was hoped . [Her]80-mrs. morland avocations above having shut out all noise but what [she]80-mrs. morland created [herself]80-mrs. morland , [she]80-mrs. morland knew not that [a visitor]2607-a visitor had arrived within the last few minutes , till , on entering [the room]1765-the room , the first object [she]80-mrs. morland beheld was [a young man whom [she]80-mrs. morland had never seen before]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before . With a look of much respect , [he]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before immediately rose , and being introduced to [her]80-mrs. morland by [[her]80-mrs. morland conscious daughter]3365-her conscious daughter as “[0-i] [Mr. Henry Tilney]95-henry , ” with the embarrassment of real sensibility began to apologize for [his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before appearance [there]1848-there , acknowledging that after what had passed [he]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before had little right to expect a welcome at [Fullerton]4-fullerton , and stating [his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before impatience to be assured of [Miss Morland]86-miss morland ’s having reached [[her]86-miss morland home]3303-her home in safety , as the cause of [his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before intrusion . [He]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before did not address [himself]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before to [an uncandid judge]3368-an uncandid judge or a resentful heart . Far from comprehending [him]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before or [[his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before sister]356-his sister in [[their]3370-their father]2482-their father ’s misconduct , [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland had been always kindly disposed towards [each]670-each , and instantly , pleased by [his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before appearance , received [him]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before with the simple professions of unaffected benevolence ; thanking [him]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before for such an attention to [[her]80-mrs. morland daughter]1729-her daughter , assuring [him]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before that [the friends of [[her]80-mrs. morland children]243-her children]3374-the friends of her children were always welcome [there]1848-there , and entreating [him]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before to say not another word of the past . [He]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before was not ill - inclined to obey this request , for , though [his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before heart was greatly relieved by such unlooked - for mildness , it was not just at that moment in [his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before power to say anything to the purpose . Returning in silence to [his]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before seat , therefore , [he]3364-a young man whom she had never seen before remained for some minutes most civilly answering all [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland ’s common remarks about the weather and [roads]3377-roads . [Catherine]76-catherine meanwhile — [the anxious , agitated , happy , feverish Catherine]3378-the anxious , agitated , happy , feverish catherine — said not a word ; but [her]3378-the anxious , agitated , happy , feverish catherine glowing cheek and brightened eye made [[her]3378-the anxious , agitated , happy , feverish catherine mother]211-her mother trust that this good - natured visit would at least set [her]3378-the anxious , agitated , happy , feverish catherine heart at ease for a time , and gladly therefore did [she]3378-the anxious , agitated , happy , feverish catherine lay aside the first volume of The Mirror for a future hour . Desirous of [Mr. Morland]105-james ’s assistance , as well in giving encouragement , as in finding conversation for [[her]80-mrs. morland guest]1054-her guest , whose embarrassment on [[his]1054-her guest father]2286-his father ’s account [she]80-mrs. morland earnestly pitied , [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland had very early dispatched [one of [the children]3383-the children]3382-one of the children to summon [him]105-james ; but [Mr. Morland]105-james was from [home]482-home — and being thus without any support , at the end of a quarter of an hour [she]80-mrs. morland had nothing to say . After a couple of minutes ’ unbroken silence , [Henry]95-henry , turning to [Catherine]76-catherine for the first time since [[her]3378-the anxious , agitated , happy , feverish catherine mother]211-her mother ’s entrance , asked [her]80-mrs. morland , with sudden alacrity , if [Mr.]3386-mr. and [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen were now at [Fullerton]4-fullerton ? And on developing , from amidst all [her]80-mrs. morland perplexity of words in reply , the meaning , which one short syllable would have given , immediately expressed [his]95-henry intention of paying [his]95-henry respects to [them]3383-the children , and , with a rising colour , asked [her]80-mrs. morland if [she]80-mrs. morland would have the goodness to show [him]95-henry the way . “[0-i] [You]1654-i may see [the house]238-the house from this window , [sir]285-sir , ” was information on [Sarah]79-sarah ’s side , which produced only a bow of acknowledgment from [the gentleman]1837-the gentleman , and a silencing nod from [[her]79-sarah mother]211-her mother ; for [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland , thinking it probable , as a secondary consideration in [his]95-henry wish of waiting on [[their]3383-the children worthy neighbours]3389-their worthy neighbours , that [he]95-henry might have some explanation to give of [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father ’s behaviour , which it must be more pleasant for [him]95-henry to communicate only to [Catherine]76-catherine , would not on any account prevent [her]80-mrs. morland accompanying [him]95-henry . [They]3383-the children began [their]3383-the children walk , and [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland was not entirely mistaken in [his]95-henry object in wishing it . Some explanation on [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father ’s account [he]95-henry had to give ; but [his]95-henry first purpose was to explain [himself]95-henry , and before [they]3383-the children reached [[Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s grounds]3392-mr. allen ’s grounds [he]95-henry had done it so well that [Catherine]76-catherine did not think it could ever be repeated too often . [She]80-mrs. morland was assured of [his]95-henry affection ; and that heart in return was solicited , which , perhaps , [they]3383-the children pretty equally knew was already entirely [his]95-henry own ; for , though [Henry]95-henry was now sincerely attached to [her]80-mrs. morland , though [he]95-henry felt and delighted in all the excellencies of [her]80-mrs. morland character and truly loved [her]80-mrs. morland society , [I]1654-i must confess that [his]95-henry affection originated in nothing better than gratitude , or , in other words , that a persuasion of [her]80-mrs. morland partiality for [him]95-henry had been the only cause of giving [her]80-mrs. morland a serious thought . It is a new circumstance in romance , [I]1654-i acknowledge , and dreadfully derogatory of [an heroine]204-an heroine ’s dignity ; but if it be as new in common life , the credit of a wild imagination will at least be all [my]1654-i own . A very short visit to [Mrs. Allen]88-mrs. allen , in which [Henry]95-henry talked at random , without sense or connection , and [Catherine]76-catherine , wrapt in the contemplation of [her]80-mrs. morland own unutterable happiness , scarcely opened [her]80-mrs. morland lips , dismissed them to the ecstasies of another tête - à - tête ; and before it was suffered to close , [she]80-mrs. morland was enabled to judge how far [he]95-henry was sanctioned by parental authority in [his]95-henry present application . On [his]95-henry return from [Woodston]64-woodston , two days before , [he]95-henry had been met near [the abbey]1248-the abbey by [[his]95-henry impatient father]3395-his impatient father , hastily informed in angry terms of [Miss Morland]86-miss morland ’s departure , and ordered to think of [her]80-mrs. morland no more . Such was the permission upon which [he]95-henry had now offered [her]80-mrs. morland [his]95-henry hand . [The affrighted Catherine]76-catherine , amidst all the terrors of expectation , as [she]80-mrs. morland listened to this account , could not but rejoice in the kind caution with which [Henry]95-henry had saved [her]80-mrs. morland from the necessity of a conscientious rejection , by engaging [her]80-mrs. morland faith before [he]95-henry mentioned the subject ; and as [he]95-henry proceeded to give the particulars , and explain the motives of [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father ’s conduct , [her]80-mrs. morland feelings soon hardened into even a triumphant delight . [The General]2216-the general had had nothing to accuse [her]80-mrs. morland of , nothing to lay to [her]80-mrs. morland charge , but [her]80-mrs. morland being the involuntary , unconscious object of a deception which [his]95-henry pride could not pardon , and which [a better pride]3398-a better pride would have been ashamed to own . [She]80-mrs. morland was guilty only of being less rich than [he]95-henry had supposed [her]80-mrs. morland to be . Under a mistaken persuasion of [her]80-mrs. morland possessions and claims , [he]95-henry had courted [her]80-mrs. morland acquaintance in [Bath]6-bath , solicited [her]80-mrs. morland company at [Northanger]62-northanger , and designed [her]80-mrs. morland for [[his]95-henry daughter - in - law]3399-his daughter - in - law . On discovering [his]95-henry error , to turn [her]80-mrs. morland from [the house]238-the house seemed the best , though to [his]95-henry feelings an inadequate proof of [his]95-henry resentment towards [herself]80-mrs. morland , and [his]95-henry contempt of [[her]80-mrs. morland family]1735-her family . [John Thorpe]99-john had first misled [him]95-henry . [The General]2216-the general , perceiving [[his]2216-the general son]824-his son one night at [the theatre]283-the theatre to be paying considerable attention to [Miss Morland]86-miss morland , had accidentally inquired of [Thorpe]99-john if [he]99-john knew more of [her]86-miss morland than [her]86-miss morland name . [Thorpe]99-john , most happy to be on speaking terms with [a man of [General Tilney]139-general tilney ’s importance]3405-a man of general tilney ’s importance , had been joyfully and proudly communicative ; and being at that time not only in daily expectation of [Morland]86-miss morland ’s engaging [Isabella]103-isabella , but likewise pretty well resolved upon marrying [Catherine]76-catherine [himself]95-henry , [his]95-henry vanity induced [him]95-henry to represent [the family]1904-the family as yet more wealthy than [his]95-henry vanity and avarice had made [him]95-henry believe [them]3407-them . With whomsoever [he]95-henry was , or was likely to be connected , [his]95-henry own consequence always required that [theirs]3408-theirs should be great , and as [his]95-henry intimacy with any acquaintance grew , so regularly grew [their]3408-theirs fortune . The expectations of [[his]95-henry friend]2002-his friend [Morland]86-miss morland , therefore , from the first overrated , had ever since [his]95-henry introduction to [Isabella]103-isabella been gradually increasing ; and by merely adding twice as much for the grandeur of the moment , by doubling what [he]95-henry chose to think the amount of [Mr. Morland]105-james ’s preferment , trebling [his]95-henry private fortune , bestowing [a rich aunt]3410-a rich aunt , and sinking half [the children]3383-the children , [he]95-henry was able to represent [the whole family]3310-the whole family to [the General]2216-the general in a most respectable light . For [Catherine]76-catherine , however , the peculiar object of [the General]2216-the general ’s curiosity , and [his]95-henry own speculations , [he]95-henry had yet something more in reserve , and the ten or fifteen thousand pounds which [[her]103-isabella father]205-her father could give [her]103-isabella would be a pretty addition to [[Mr. Allen]85-mr. allen ’s estate]3416-mr. allen ’s estate . [Her]103-isabella intimacy there had made [him]95-henry seriously determine on [her]103-isabella being handsomely legacied hereafter ; and to speak of [her]103-isabella therefore as [the almost acknowledged future heiress of [Fullerton]4-fullerton]3417-the almost acknowledged future heiress of fullerton naturally followed . Upon such intelligence [the General]2216-the general had proceeded ; for never had it occurred to [him]95-henry to doubt [its]2216-the general authority . [Thorpe]103-isabella ’s interest in [the family]1904-the family , by [[his]95-henry sister]356-his sister ’s approaching connection with [one of [[its]1904-the family members]3422-its members]3421-one of its members , and [his]95-henry own views on another ( circumstances of which [he]95-henry boasted with almost equal openness ) , seemed sufficient vouchers for [his]95-henry truth ; and to these were added the absolute facts of [the Allens]106-the allens being wealthy and childless , of [Miss Morland]86-miss morland ’s being under [their]106-the allens care , and — as soon as [his]95-henry acquaintance allowed [him]95-henry to judge — of [their]106-the allens treating [her]86-miss morland with parental kindness . [His]95-henry resolution was soon formed . Already had [he]95-henry discerned a liking towards [Miss Morland]86-miss morland in the countenance of [[his]95-henry son]824-his son ; and thankful for [Mr. Thorpe]120-mr. thorpe ’s communication , [he]95-henry almost instantly determined to spare no pains in weakening [his]95-henry boasted interest and ruining [his]95-henry dearest hopes . [Catherine]76-catherine [herself]76-catherine could not be more ignorant at the time of all this , than [[his]95-henry own children]3424-his own children . [Henry]95-henry and [Eleanor]143-eleanor , perceiving nothing in [her]86-miss morland situation likely to engage [[their]106-the allens father]2482-their father ’s particular respect , had seen with astonishment the suddenness , continuance , and extent of [his]95-henry attention ; and though latterly , from some hints which had accompanied an almost positive command to [[his]95-henry son]824-his son of doing everything in [his]95-henry power to attach [her]86-miss morland , [Henry]95-henry was convinced of [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father ’s believing it to be an advantageous connection , it was not till the late explanation at [Northanger]62-northanger that [they]106-the allens had the smallest idea of the false calculations which had hurried [him]95-henry on . That they were false , [the General]2216-the general had learnt from [the very person who had suggested [them]106-the allens , from [Thorpe]120-mr. thorpe [himself]120-mr. thorpe , whom [he]120-mr. thorpe had chanced to meet again in [town]427-town , and who , under the influence of exactly opposite feelings , irritated by [Catherine]76-catherine ’s refusal , and yet more by the failure of a very recent endeavour to accomplish a reconciliation between [Morland]86-miss morland and [Isabella]103-isabella]3429-the very person who had suggested them , from thorpe himself , whom he had chanced to meet again in town , and who , under the influence of exactly opposite feelings , irritated by catherine ’s refusal , and yet more by the failure of a very recent endeavour to accomplish a reconciliation between morland and isabella , convinced that [they]106-the allens were separated forever , and spurning a friendship which could be no longer serviceable , hastened to contradict all that [he]2216-the general had said before to the advantage of [the Morlands]78-the morlands — confessed [himself]2216-the general to have been totally mistaken in [his]2216-the general opinion of [their]106-the allens circumstances and character , misled by the rhodomontade of [[his]2216-the general friend]2002-his friend to believe [[his]2216-the general father]2286-his father [a man of substance and credit]3433-a man of substance and credit , whereas the transactions of the two or three last weeks proved [him]2216-the general to be neither ; for after coming eagerly forward on the first overture of a marriage between [the families]3434-the families , with the most liberal proposals , [he]2216-the general had , on being brought to the point by the shrewdness of [the relator]3435-the relator , been constrained to acknowledge [himself]2216-the general incapable of giving [the young people]2472-the young people even a decent support . [They]2472-the young people were , in fact , [a necessitous family]3437-a necessitous family ; numerous , too , almost beyond example ; by no means respected in [[their]2472-the young people own neighbourhood]3438-their own neighbourhood , as [he]2216-the general had lately had particular opportunities of discovering ; aiming at a style of life which [their]2472-the young people fortune could not warrant ; seeking to better [themselves]2472-the young people by wealthy connections ; [a forward , bragging , scheming race]3439-a forward , bragging , scheming race . [The terrified General]3440-the terrified general pronounced the name of [Allen]85-mr. allen with an inquiring look ; and here too [Thorpe]120-mr. thorpe had learnt [his]120-mr. thorpe error . [The Allens]106-the allens , [he]2216-the general believed , had lived near [them]106-the allens too long , and [he]2216-the general knew [the young man on whom [the Fullerton estate]3442-the fullerton estate]3441-the young man on whom the fullerton estate must devolve . [The General]2216-the general needed no more . Enraged with almost everybody in [the world]215-the world but [himself]2216-the general , [he]2216-the general set out the next day for [the abbey]1248-the abbey , where [his]2216-the general performances have been seen . [I]1654-i leave it to [[my]1654-i reader]3446-my reader ’s sagacity to determine how much of all this it was possible for [Henry]95-henry to communicate at this time to [Catherine]76-catherine , how much of it [he]95-henry could have learnt from [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father , in what points [his]95-henry own conjectures might assist [him]95-henry , and what portion must yet remain to be told in a letter from [James]105-james . [I]1654-i have united for [their]3448-their ease what [they]3448-their must divide for [mine]1654-i . [Catherine]76-catherine , at any rate , heard enough to feel that in suspecting [General Tilney]139-general tilney of either murdering or shutting up [[his]139-general tilney wife]1799-his wife , [she]1799-his wife had scarcely sinned against [his]139-general tilney character , or magnified [his]139-general tilney cruelty . [Henry]95-henry , in having such things to relate of [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father , was almost as pitiable as in [their]3448-their first avowal to [himself]95-henry . [He]95-henry blushed for the narrow - minded counsel which [he]95-henry was obliged to expose . The conversation between [them]3448-their at [Northanger]62-northanger had been of the most unfriendly kind . [Henry]95-henry ’s indignation on hearing how [Catherine]76-catherine had been treated , on comprehending [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father ’s views , and being ordered to acquiesce in them , had been open and bold . [The General]2216-the general , accustomed on every ordinary occasion to give the law in [[his]2216-the general family]1879-his family , prepared for no reluctance but of feeling , no opposing desire that should dare to clothe itself in words , could ill brook the opposition of [[his]2216-the general son]824-his son , steady as the sanction of reason and the dictate of conscience could make it . But , in such a cause , [his]2216-the general anger , though it must shock , could not intimidate [Henry]95-henry , who was sustained in [his]95-henry purpose by a conviction of its justice . [He]95-henry felt [himself]95-henry bound as much in honour as in affection to [Miss Morland]86-miss morland , and believing that heart to be [his]95-henry own which [he]95-henry had been directed to gain , no unworthy retraction of a tacit consent , no reversing decree of unjustifiable anger , could shake [his]95-henry fidelity , or influence the resolutions it prompted . [He]95-henry steadily refused to accompany [[his]95-henry father]2286-his father into [Herefordshire]73-herefordshire , an engagement formed almost at the moment to promote the dismissal of [Catherine]76-catherine , and as steadily declared [his]95-henry intention of offering [her]86-miss morland [his]95-henry hand . [The General]2216-the general was furious in [his]2216-the general anger , and [they]3457-they parted in dreadful disagreement . [Henry]95-henry , in an agitation of mind which many solitary hours were required to compose , had returned almost instantly to [Woodston]64-woodston , and , on the afternoon of the following day , had begun [his]95-henry journey to [Fullerton]4-fullerton . CHAPTER 31 [Mr.]3458-mr. and [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland ’s surprise on being applied to by [Mr. Tilney]95-henry for [their]3457-they consent to [his]95-henry marrying [[their]3457-they daughter]2533-their daughter was , for a few minutes , considerable , it having never entered [their]3457-they heads to suspect an attachment on either side ; but as nothing , after all , could be more natural than [Catherine]76-catherine ’s being beloved , [they]3457-they soon learnt to consider it with only the happy agitation of gratified pride , and , as far as [they]3457-they alone were concerned , had not a single objection to start . [His]95-henry pleasing manners and good sense were self - evident recommendations ; and having never heard evil of [him]95-henry , it was not [their]3457-they way to suppose any evil could be told . [Goodwill]190-goodwill supplying the place of experience , [his]95-henry character needed no attestation . “[1654-i] [Catherine]76-catherine would make [a sad , heedless young housekeeper]1657-a sad , heedless young housekeeper to be sure , ” was [[her]2533-their daughter mother]211-her mother ’s foreboding remark ; but quick was the consolation of there being nothing like practice . There was but one obstacle , in short , to be mentioned ; but till that one was removed , it must be impossible for [them]3457-they to sanction the engagement . [Their]3457-they tempers were mild , but [their]3457-they principles were steady , and while [[his]95-henry parent]3461-his parent so expressly forbade the connection , [they]3457-they could not allow [themselves]3457-they to encourage it . That [the General]2216-the general should come forward to solicit the alliance , or that [he]2216-the general should even very heartily approve it , [they]3457-they were not refined enough to make any parading stipulation ; but the decent appearance of consent must be yielded , and that once obtained — and [their]3457-they own hearts made [them]3457-they trust that it could not be very long denied — [their]3457-they willing approbation was instantly to follow . [His]95-henry _ consent _ was all that [they]3457-they wished for . [They]3457-they were no more inclined than entitled to demand [his]95-henry _ money _ . Of a very considerable fortune , [[his]95-henry son]824-his son was , by marriage settlements , eventually secure ; [his]824-his son present income was an income of independence and comfort , and under every pecuniary view , it was a match beyond the claims of [[their]3457-they daughter]2533-their daughter . [The young people]2472-the young people could not be surprised at a decision like this . [They]3457-they felt and [they]3457-they deplored — but [they]3457-they could not resent it ; and [they]3457-they parted , endeavouring to hope that such a change in [the General]2216-the general , as [each]670-each believed almost impossible , might speedily take place , to unite [them]3457-they again in the fulness of privileged affection . [Henry]95-henry returned to what was now [[his]95-henry only home]3468-his only home , to watch over [[his]95-henry young plantations]3469-his young plantations , and extend [his]95-henry improvements for [her]2533-their daughter sake , to whose share in them [he]95-henry looked anxiously forward ; and [Catherine]76-catherine remained at [Fullerton]4-fullerton to cry . Whether the torments of absence were softened by a clandestine correspondence , let [us]3470-us not inquire . [Mr.]3471-mr. and [Mrs. Morland]80-mrs. morland never did — [they]3457-they had been too kind to exact any promise ; and whenever [Catherine]76-catherine received a letter , as , at that time , happened pretty often , [they]3457-they always looked another way . The anxiety , which in this state of [their]3457-they attachment must be the portion of [Henry]95-henry and [Catherine]76-catherine , and of [all who loved either , as to its final event]3472-all who loved either , as to its final event , can hardly extend , [I]1657-a sad , heedless young housekeeper fear , to the bosom of [[my]1657-a sad , heedless young housekeeper readers]3473-my readers , who will see in the tell - tale compression of the pages before [them]3473-my readers , that [we]3470-us are all hastening together to perfect felicity . The means by which [their]3457-they early marriage was effected can be the only doubt : what probable circumstance could work upon a temper like [the General]2216-the general ’s ? The circumstance which chiefly availed was the marriage of [[his]95-henry daughter]598-his daughter with [a man of fortune and consequence , which took place in the course of the summer]3476-a man of fortune and consequence , which took place in the course of the summer — an accession of dignity that threw [him]95-henry into a fit of good humour , from which [he]95-henry did not recover till after [Eleanor]143-eleanor had obtained [his]143-eleanor forgiveness of [Henry]95-henry , and [his]143-eleanor permission for [him]95-henry “[1657-a sad , heedless young housekeeper] to be [a fool]793-a fool if [he]1659-he liked it ! ” The marriage of [Eleanor Tilney]143-eleanor , [her]598-his daughter removal from all the evils of [such a home as [Northanger]62-northanger]3477-such a home as northanger had been made by [Henry]95-henry ’s banishment , to [the home of [her]598-his daughter choice]3478-the home of her choice and [the man of [her]598-his daughter choice]3479-the man of her choice , is an event which [I]1660-i expect to give general satisfaction among all [her]598-his daughter acquaintance . [My]1660-i own joy on the occasion is very sincere . [I]1660-i know [no one more entitled , by unpretending merit]3480-no one more entitled , by unpretending merit , or better prepared by habitual suffering , to receive and enjoy felicity . [Her]598-his daughter partiality for [this gentleman]3481-this gentleman was not of recent origin ; and [he]3481-this gentleman had been long withheld only by inferiority of situation from addressing [her]598-his daughter . [His]3481-this gentleman unexpected accession to title and fortune had removed all [his]3481-this gentleman difficulties ; and never had [the General]2216-the general loved [[his]2216-the general daughter]598-his daughter so well in all [her]1662-her hours of companionship , utility , and patient endurance as when [he]2216-the general first hailed [her]1662-her “[1660-i] [[Your]1660-i Ladyship]1661-your ladyship ! ” [[Her]1662-her husband]2226-her husband was really deserving of [her]1662-her ; independent of [his]2226-her husband peerage , [his]2226-her husband wealth , and [his]2226-her husband attachment , being to a precision [the most charming young man in [the world]215-the world]1664-the most charming young man in the world . Any further definition of [his]2226-her husband merits must be unnecessary ; [the most charming young man in [the world]215-the world]1664-the most charming young man in the world is instantly before the imagination of [us]1668-us all . Concerning [the one in question]1669-the one in question , therefore , [I]0-i have only to add — aware that the rules of composition forbid the introduction of [a character not connected with [my]0-i fable]1670-a character not connected with my fable — that this was [the very gentleman whose negligent servant left behind [him]2226-her husband that collection of washing - bills , resulting from a long visit at [Northanger]62-northanger , by which [[my]0-i heroine]2201-my heroine was involved in one of [her]2201-my heroine most alarming adventures]1671-the very gentleman whose negligent servant left behind him that collection of washing - bills , resulting from a long visit at northanger , by which my heroine was involved in one of her most alarming adventures . The influence of [the Viscount]1673-the viscount and [Viscountess]191-viscountess in [[their]1674-their brother]3085-their brother ’s behalf was assisted by that right understanding of [Mr. Morland]105-james ’s circumstances which , as soon as [the General]2216-the general would allow [himself]2216-the general to be informed , [they]1674-their were qualified to give . It taught [him]2216-the general that [he]2216-the general had been scarcely more misled by [Thorpe]120-mr. thorpe ’s first boast of the family wealth than by [his]2216-the general subsequent malicious overthrow of it ; that in no sense of the word were [they]1674-their necessitous or poor , and that [Catherine]76-catherine would have three thousand pounds . This was so material an amendment of [his]2216-the general late expectations that it greatly contributed to smooth the descent of [his]2216-the general pride ; and by no means without its effect was the private intelligence , which [he]2216-the general was at some pains to procure , that [the Fullerton estate]3442-the fullerton estate , being entirely at the disposal of [[its]3442-the fullerton estate present proprietor]1678-its present proprietor , was consequently open to every greedy speculation . On the strength of this , [the General]2216-the general , soon after [Eleanor]143-eleanor ’s marriage , permitted [[his]2216-the general son]824-his son to return to [Northanger]62-northanger , and thence made [him]824-his son the bearer of [his]2216-the general consent , very courteously worded in a page full of empty professions to [Mr. Morland]105-james . The event which it authorized soon followed : [Henry]95-henry and [Catherine]76-catherine were married , the bells rang , and [everybody]1780-everybody smiled ; and , as this took place within a twelvemonth from the first day of [their]1674-their meeting , it will not appear , after all the dreadful delays occasioned by [the General]2216-the general ’s cruelty , that [they]1674-their were essentially hurt by it . To begin perfect happiness at the respective ages of twenty - six and eighteen is to do pretty well ; and professing [myself]0-i moreover convinced that [the General]2216-the general ’s unjust interference , so far from being really injurious to [their]1674-their felicity , was perhaps rather conducive to it , by improving [their]1674-their knowledge of [each other]1792-each other , and adding strength to [their]1674-their attachment , [I]0-i leave it to be settled , by whomsoever it may concern , whether the tendency of this work be altogether to recommend parental tyranny , or reward filial disobedience . A NOTE ON THE TEXT [Northanger Abbey]1-northanger abbey was written in 1797–98 under a different title . The manuscript was revised around 1803 and sold to a [London]12-london publisher , [Crosbie & Co.]74-crosbie & co. , who sold it back in 1816 . The Signet Classic text is based on the first edition , published by [John Murray]192-john murray , [London]12-london , in 1818 — the year following [Miss Austen]193-miss austen ’s death . Spelling and punctuation have been largely brought into conformity with modern British usage . * * * END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK [NORTHANGER ABBEY]1-northanger abbey * * *
